She is grateful for the opportunity provided by this means and pledges to repay in a timely fashion.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy merchandise, like blankets, to increase stock inventory.

loans.name: José Orlando

texts.es:
José tiene 21 años de edad, es soltero y vive junto a su madre en el centro poblado menor Cruz del Médano, distrito de Mórrope, ubicado a 45 minutos de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Hace tres años fue a trabajar en un taller de confección de ropa de la ciudad de Lima y con el dinero que ganaba ayudó a su madre a instalar una pequeña bodega en su casa. Con este negocio su madre pudo salir adelante y solventar sus gastos mientras trabajaba fuera de su hogar.

Ahora que ha regresado, José planea ampliar la bodega y seguir sacando adelante a su madre por ello ha solicitado por primera vez a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 1000 nuevos soles para comprar más productos de primera necesidad y abarrotes.

Su más grande anhelo es empezar a trabajar independientemente confeccionando ropa. El es un joven responsable y muy emprendedor.
texts.en:
Jose is 21 years old, single, and lives with his mother in an area called Cruz del Médano, in the district of Morrope, which is located 45 minutes from the city of Chiclayo. Jose went to work in a clothing factory in Lima three years ago and was therefore able to help his mother install a small grocery store in her home with the money he earned. His mother has been able to get ahead by having this shop and pay her bills all the while working from home. Now that he has returned, Jose plans to make the store bigger and continue to help his mother get ahead. This is why he is taking out his first loan of 1000 soles with EDPYME Altervativa, so he can buy more groceries and basic necessities for the shop. His greatest dream is to work for himself making clothing. He is young, responsible, and very enterprising.

Translated from Spanish by Shelly Hubman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase basic necesities, groceries, and grow the business.

loans.name: Avon Group

texts.es: María Catalina M. A., Ninet Carolina B., Jahaira Aracelly L. H. y  Daysi María
texts.en: María Catalina M. A., Ninet Carolina B., Jahaira Aracelly L. H. and  Daysi María

loans.use: To buy clothing.

loans.name: Lester Enrique

texts.es:
El Señor Lester Enrique Blandón A. tiene a su cargo dos hijos, esta casado, ha trabajado con Ceprodel durante dos años y medio, en ese lapso ha logrado mejorar las condiciones de su vivienda con los 2 créditos que ha trabajado con Ceprodel, el es un excelente cliente ha pagado sus créditos en el tiempo estimado.

El crédito solicitado es para invertir en compra de materiales para la construcción de un cuarto de habitación, con el fin de darle un mejor estilo de vida a su Familia.
texts.en:
Mr. Lester Enrique B. A. is married, has two children, and has been working with Ceprodel for two and a half years. He has used two Ceprodel loans to improve his family's living conditions. He is an excellent customer and he always makes his payments on time. His newest loan will allow him to buy the materials he needs to build a fourth room in his house and improve his family's quality of living.

Translated from Spanish by Corinne Gilroy, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Building materials for home renovations

loans.name: Vilma Lisseth

texts.es:
La señora Vilma Lisseth L. L. de 43 años desde hace dieciocho años que comercializa de manera ambulante ropa, zapatos, prenda y cosmético. Ella asegura que se siente con mayor libertad, con capacidad y segura de sí misma, ya que aporta a la casa  y  es independiente.
Ella invertirá su crédito para adquirir mercadería en ropa, zapatos, prendas y cosméticos, además de aprovechar la temporada navideña.
texts.en:
Mrs. Vilma Lisseth L. Lopez is 43 years old. She has been selling clothing, shoes and cosmetics for eighteen years. Her work allows her to feel free and secure-- and confident that she is contributing to her household. Vilma will use this loan to purchase more merchandise, including more clothing, shoes and cosmetics. She will also use a little to help her celebrate the Holidays.

Translated from Spanish by Corinne Gilroy, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying clothing, shoes and cosmetics and jewellery

loans.name: José

texts.es:
José tiene 58 años de edad, es casado, padre de 7 hijos ya independizados y vive junto a su esposa en el caserío Quemazón, distrito de Mórrope, ubicado a 45 minutos de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Desde que tenía 20 años de edad empezó a criar animales para venderlos. Usualmente compra ganado caprino, ovino, porcino y aves de corral para criarlos y luego ir a venderlos dos veces por mes a la ciudad de Chiclayo. Este negocio es el único ingreso permanente con el que cuenta ya que también se dedica a la agricultura pero esta actividad sólo le brinda ingresos por temporadas.

Gracias al negocio de la venta de animales ha podido sacar adelante a sus hijos. José desea ampliar su negocio pero no cuenta con el capital suficiente para realizar esta acción por lo está solicitando a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 1000 nuevos soles que piensa invertir en la compra de más animales.

José desea seguir trabajando e invertir las ganancias en el mejoramiento de su hogar ya que las fuertes lluvias de los años anteriores han mermado las estructuras y estas no soportarían otra temporada de lluvias. El es muy resposable y entregado a su familia. Ya ha trabajado con nuestra Institución anteriormente y ha demostrado ser un cliente responsable al momento de asumir sus pagos.
texts.en:
José is 58 years old, married, and the father of 7 children who now live independently. He and his wife live in the village of Quemazón, Mórrope District, which is located 45 minutes away from the city of Chiclayo.

When he was 20 years old, José started raising animals to sell. He usually buys goats, sheep, pigs, and chickens to raise. Twice a month, he travels to Chiclayo to sell animals. This business is his only steady source of income. José also engages in farming, but the income from his crop harvests is on a seasonal basis.

Thanks to his business of buying and selling animals, José was able to support his children. He wants to expand his business, but he does not have enough available capital. Therefore, he is requesting a loan from Edpyme Alternativa in the amount of 1000 soles so that he can purchase more animals.

José wants to continue working so that he can invest his profits in making home improvements. Heavy rains over the years have eroded the infrastructure of his house, making it incapable of withstanding another rainy season. He is very responsible and extremely devoted to his family. José has worked with our Institution previously and has demonstrated that he is a responsible client when it comes to making his payments.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase more animals to sell

loans.name: Brisas Del Mar Group

texts.es:
El grupo las Brisas del Mar está integrado por tres mujeres únicas que han luchado arduamente por sus familias, una de ellas es Leticia M.. Esta señora vende en su casa de habitación carne, pollo y refrescos naturales lo cual le ha ayudado a su economía y le ha hecho sentirse productiva.
 Ubania P. tiene una barbería la cual atiende con su esposo además brinda servicios a domicilio de manicure, pedicura, corte de cabello, planchados y alisados entre otros. Mientras Margarita M. produce y vende nacatamales y ropa nacional de calidad.
texts.en:
The group, "Brisas del Mar," (Sea Breezes) is made up of three unique women who have fought hard for their families. One of them is Leticia M.. This woman sells meat, chicken, and natural juices in her home, which has helped her finances and has made her feel productive. Ubania P. has a barber shop to which she attends with her husband. She also goes to people's homes to do manicures, pedicures, hair cuts, hair straightening, conditioning, etc. Margarita M. makes and sells nacatamales (Nicaraguan tamales) and quality national clothing.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase beef and chicken

loans.name: Sonia

texts.en:
Sonia C. is from the village of Marapong. She is 55 years old. Sonia is married and has 3 adult children. To make a living, Sonia sells daily-use products such as shampoo, soap, and toothpaste in the local community. Sonia has been engaged in her business for over 7 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2008, Sonia joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Sonia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3000 PHP from PMPC. Sonia is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP to purchase additional products to sell. This will be Sonia's second loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Las Pepas Group

texts.es:
El grupo las Pepas está integrado por mujeres trabajadoras, capaces y emprendedoras que han sabido salir adelante estás son Sadia S., Elizabeth M. y María C.. Ellas necesitan el crédito para cubrir la demanda de sus clientes ya que en esta época se las ventas suben.
Sadia S. de veintisiete años tiene nueve años de vender ropa, Elizabeth M. vende nacatamales, frito, chicharrón, moronga, chancho con yuca y carne de cerdo y María C. vende tortillas y leche de soya.
texts.en:
The group “Las Pepas” consists of three hardworking, capable, and enterprising women who want to succeed: Sadia S., Elizabeth M., and María C.. They need a loan so that they can meet the increased demand from their customers that occurs during this time of the year.

Sadia S. is 27 years old and has been selling clothes for 9 years. Elizabeth M. sells nacatamales, fried pork, chicharrones, blood sausage, pork with cassava, and other dishes. María C. sells tortillas and soy milk.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Operating capital for their respective businesses

loans.name: Fortunata

texts.en:
Fortunata B. is from the town of Rizal. She is 56 years old. Fortunata is married and has 3 adult children. To make a living, Fortunata makes and sells ice cream in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over 7 years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2008, Fortunata joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Fortunata has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from PMPC. Fortunata is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP to expand her business. This will be Fortunata's second loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's living conditions. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.name: La Pintura Group

texts.es:
Marcia A., Lisseth A., Dina M. y Ruth A. conforman al grupo La Pintura.  Ellas son mujeres trabajadoras y emprendedoras que han administrado de forma formidable sus negocios. 
Dina Rebeca M. empezó vendiendo lápices y cuadernos, pero poco a poco su negocio fue creciendo hasta convertirlo en un cafetín y librería escolar. Asimismo paso con Marcia Nohemí A. quien inició con la venta de fresco y hoy en día vende comida y queso. 
Ruth A. vende ropa de diferentes estilos y Lisseth Jaqueline A. vende golosinas y helados. Todas ellas invertirán sus créditos en sus negocios para mejorarlos y aumentar sus ganancias.
texts.en:
Marcia A., Lisseth A., Dina M., and Ruth A. make up the group named “La Pintura” (The Painting). They are hardworking and enterprising women who have managed their businesses admirably.

Dina Rebeca M. began selling pencils and notebooks. Her business grew over time until it was eventually converted into a café and school bookstore. Around the same time, Marcia Nohemí A. started a business selling soft drinks. Today she sells prepared foods and cheese.

Ruth A. sells different styles of clothing, while Lisseth Jaqueline A. sells candy and ice cream. They all are requesting loans to invest in their businesses so they can increase their revenues and improve their income.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Operating capital for their respective businesses

loans.name: Jean

texts.en:
Jean G. is from the village of Dapacan Alto. She is 29 years old. Jean is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Jean raises and sells pigs. Jean has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 700 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2007, Jean joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jean has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC. Jean is requesting a new loan of 3000 PHP to purchase piglets that she will raise and sell in the future. This will be Jean's 5th loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's living conditions.

To make a living, Mary Jane sells  daily-use products such as shampoo, soap, and toothpaste in the local community. Mary Jane has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 800 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2008, Mary Jane joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Mary Jane is requesting a loan of 3000 PHP to buy additional inventory and use as working capital. This will be Mary Jane's first loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's living conditions.

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.use: To buy additional inventory and use as working capital

loans.name: Gloria Esperanza

texts.es:
La señora Gloria Esperanza C. de 65 años tiene un pequeño negocio que consiste en una pulpería y destace de cerdo de donde produce alimentos del cerdo como es el nacatamal, el frito, la moronga y el chicharro entre otros.	
Esta es una actividad común en la familia nicaragüense y una alternativa económica para ayudar a generar ingresos a la familia. Además tiene gran de manda en el país en especial los fines de semana para el desayuno, el almuerzo o la cena.
texts.en:
Sra. Gloria Esperanza C. is 65 years old and has a small business that consists of a grocery store and a food stand where she prepares pork dishes such as nacatamales, fried pork, blood sausage, and chicharrones among other items.

Cooking is a common activity in Nicaraguan families and provides a financial alternative for generating household income. Sra. Gloria has earned a fine reputation throughout most of the country, especially for the breakfasts, lunches, and dinners she serves on the weekends.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy pork

loans.name: Isis Group

texts.es:
El grupo Isis está integrado por cuatro mujeres trabajadoras y muy capaces ellas son Martha, Jenny, Karen y Brenda.  La señora Martha Elizabeth R. S. comercializa ropa de todo tipo y utensilios para el hogar. Ella inicio con este negocio para poder sacar a sus hijos adelante y que contaran con la educación que a ella le falto.
De la misma manera sus compañeras de grupo Jenny Montiel R., Karen Esperanza G. y Brenda del Socorro A. B.  se ganan el pan de cada día vendiendo ropa de manera ambulante. Ellas actualmente necesitan de mayor inversión por la demanda de de sus clientes en esta época del año.
texts.en:
The Isis Group consists of four hardworking, capable women: Martha, Jenny, Karen, and Brenda.

Sra. Martha Elizabeth R. S. sells all types of clothing and household utensils. She started this business so that her children could get ahead and receive the education that she was not able to obtain.

Her fellow group members – Jenny Montiel R., Karen Esperanza G., and Brenda del Socorro A. B. – all make their living by selling clothes as street vendors. They currently need more capital to meet the customer demand during this time of the year.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Operating capital to purchase more clothing

loans.name: Juan Ramon

texts.es:
El Señor Juan Ramos B. tiene a su cargo tres hijos, esta casado, ha trabajado créditos con Ceprodel durante seis años, en ese lapso ha logrado mejorar las condiciones de su vivienda con los 7 financiamiento que ha trabajado con Ceprodel, el es un excelente cliente y puntual en sus pagos.

El crédito solicitado es para invertir en la compra de materiales para la remodelación del techo de la vivienda y el pago de la mano de obra de la construcción.
texts.en:
Sr. Juan Ramos B. is married and has three children. He has worked with CEPRODEL for 6 years and, during this time, he has been able to improve his living conditions with the 7 previous loans he has received. He is an excellent client who has been punctual with his payments.

The loan he is requesting now will be used to purchase materials and pay for labor required to refurbish the roof of his house.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Pay for materials & labor needed to refurbish the roof of his house

loans.name: Milagrosa

Milagrosa M. is from the village of Landing. She is 55 years old. Milagrosa is married and has 6 adult children. To make a living, Milagrosa sells daily-use products such as shampoo, soap, and toothpaste in the local community. Milagrosa has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2005, Milagrosa joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Milagrosa has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC. Milagrosa is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP to purchase additional products to sell. This will be Milagrosa's ninth loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's living conditions. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.name: Benjamin Group

texts.es:
El grupo Benjamín está integrado por Liliam, Blanca y Orfanelia tres mujeres excepcionales que han trabajado arduamente por sus familias y donde se han encontrado con ellas mismas.
Liliam de Jesús R. vende desde hace seis años frijoles, pan y ropa usada, Blanca Rosa J. vende nacatamales, pan y cosméticos y Orfanelia P. comercializa cuajadas chontaleñas que son de las mejores en Nicaragua.
texts.en:
The Benjamin Group consists of Liliam, Blanca, and Orfanelia. These three exceptional women have worked hard to get where they are today in order to support their families.

Liliam de Jesús R. has been selling beans, bread, and used clothing for six years. Blanca Rosa J. sells nacatamales, bread, and cosmetics. Orfanelia P. sells cuajadas (milk custards) from Chontales, which are the best in Nicaragua.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Operating capital for their respective businesses

loans.name: Las Tranquilas Group

texts.es:
El Grupo Las Tranquilas está integrado por  Luz María U. M., Martha Avelleneth A. G. y Maryuri del Carmen M. E.. Ellas habitan en el barrio San Judas el cual se ha destacado por su religiosidad y beligerancia  por los derechos y las necesidades de sus pobladores.

Luz U. M. comercializa productos de limpieza de manera ambulante, Martha A. G. vende productos esquimos en su casa y Maryuri M. E. vende Cd y DVD de manera ambulante.
texts.en:
The group “Las Tranquilas” (The Quiet Ones) consists of El Grupo Las Tranquilas está integrado por Luz María U. M., Martha Avelleneth A. G. and Maryuri del Carmen M. E.. They lives in the neighborhood of San Judas, which is known for its religious and revolutionary struggles to gain basic rights and necessities for its residents. S Luz U. M. sells cleaning products as a street vendor. Martha A. G. sells Eskimo brand ice cream products out of her home. Maryuri M. E. sells CDs and DVDs as a street vendor.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Operating capital for their respective businesses

loans.name: Yolanda

texts.en:
Yolanda M.’s love for cooking made her an entrepreneur of more than twenty years.  She makes a living for her family because of her culinary talent.  She is now 46 years old and lives with her husband Eduard and their four children in Parola, Binondo, Manila.
 
She has a small eatery which caters to employees, students and drivers.  Customer traffic is so high especially during lunch time so she hired a canteen assistant.  Yolanda earns P100,000 a month from her food business.  She is saving much of her profits to build up funds for her new business venture – an apartment, the construction of which is now underway.  

Yolanda was among the first members of the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative in her community.  She joined the cooperative in 2000.  She used her previous loans from the cooperative to sustain her business.  Now on her ninth loan cycle, she needs a loan of P25, 000 as additional capital for her eatery.  She will use the funds to purchase raw ingredients for her eatery (fresh pork, chicken, assorted vegetables, fish and rice).  Yolanda dreams of having a cozy restaurant soon.  



About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice.  This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context.  It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.  CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: purchase of raw ingredients for her food business

loans.name: Elvie

texts.en:
Elvie L. is from the town of Lapasan Clarin Misamis Occidental. She is 27 years old, married, and has 2 infant-aged children. To make a living, Elvie owns and operates a a general store in the retail sector. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling daily toiletries such as shampoo, soap, and toothpaste in the local community. Elvie has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Elvie joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elvie has successfully repaid a previous loan of 40,000 PHP from GDMPC. Elvie is requesting a new loan of 30,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell in her store. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Elvie from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fishermen, and small entrepreneurs.

loans.use: Purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Los Coco Group

texts.es:
El grupo los coco está integrado  tres mujeres comerciantes de ropa una de ellas es  Santito Alejandra G. G. quien vende ropa de adulto de todos los estilos. Mientras  Eveling Johana M. M. que comercializa ropa usada y Edigcia Jeanneth M. M. vende ropa infantil e interior de calidad. 
Ellas invertirán el crédito para comprar ropa al por mayor y aprovechar esta temporada navideña.
texts.en:
The group “Los Coco” consists of three businesswomen who sell clothing. Santito Alejandra G. G. sells all styles of clothing for adults. Eveling Johana M. M. sells used clothing. Edigcia Jeanneth M. M. sells children’s clothing and high quality undergarments.

They are requesting a loan to buy clothing in bulk so that they can take advantage of the holiday season.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase clothing to sell for the holiday season

loans.name: Tserendorj

texts.en: Tserendorj is 31 years old and lives with his wife and 5-year-old son in Hovd province, one of Mongolia's western provinces. His son goes to a local kindergarten. Tserendorj has a small retail business with his wife. They sell meat at the local food marketplace called Han-Ord. Tserendorj usually purchases livestock, including sheep, cattle and goat, from herder families in the countryside and sells their meat in small pieces at the market. His wife usually sells the meat while he collects the livestock and prepares them for retail. They have been in the business since 2005 and their business capital has expanded from 300,000 MNT to 1,000,000 MNT ($1 = 1,450 MNT) to date. Tserendorj says that he would like to purchase livestock at this time of the year as meat prices hit the seasonal low and resell them in the spring when prices pick up. He requests a loan to purchase more livestock for his business. About XacBank XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save. To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team. To lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click here.

loans.use: To purchase more livestock

loans.name: Lina

texts.en:
Lina V. is a 53-year-old woman living in the town of Asau. She is married and has 5 children. To make a living, Lina owns & operates a business venture in the arts sector, operating a handicraft business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling clay handicrafts to tourists and local community members. Lina has been engaged in this business for over 2 years and earns approximately 400 WST a month from these activities.

In 2008, Lina joined SPBD to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 750 WST from SPBD. This previous loan was used to purchase additional handicrafts to sell. Lina is now requesting a new loan of 1450 WST which will be used to purchase additional handicrafts to sell. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by the borrower from SPBD. Lina plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About SPBD:

SPBD's mission is to improve the quality of life of people living in poverty in the poor island nations of the South Pacific. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based on a respect for each individual's innate human ingenuity, drive and self esteem.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Ruta P. is a 42-year-old woman living in the town of Sataua Uta. She is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Ruta owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector, raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting & harvesting taro for sale. Ruta has been engaged in this business for over 3 years and earns approximately 400 WST a month from these activities.

In 2008, Ruta joined SPBD to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ruta has successfully repaid a previous loan of 750 WST from SPBD. This previous loan was used to rent land to raise additional crops. Ruta is now requesting a new loan of 1450 WST which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by the borrower from SPBD. Ruta plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family.

About SPBD:

loans.name: Tessie

texts.en:
Mrs. Tessie A. is from the village of Landing in Baliangao, Misamis Occidental. She is 43 years old. She is married and blessed with 3 adult children. To make a living, Tessie provides transportation on her motorcycle to members of the local community. She has been engaged on her business for more than 5 years and earns 5,000.00 monthly from her business.

Tessie joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.Tessie is requesting a new loan of 36,000.00 PHP to purchase a motorcycle to transport passengers. This will be Tessie's 8th loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's living conditions. 

About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy a motorcycle to transport passengers

loans.name: Batmonh

texts.en:
Batmonh G. is 37 years old and lives with his wife and three children in Hovd province, one of Mongolia's western provinces. His three teenage children are students in a local secondary school. Batmonh does a small business in carpentry with his wife. He is a talented carpenter who makes traditional wooden furniture for locals. His wife sells his furniture at the local market where she rents a stall for the products. Batmonh has been running a small carpentry shop with one assistant since 2004, his assistant being paid according to his contribution on each furniture project. In addition to his furniture-making business, his family also has a small farm with about 20 pigs and five chickens. They sell the eggs from their chickens and plan to sell their pigs during this year’s New Year celebrations when pork prices peak.

Batmonh says that he would like to expand both his furniture business and his small farm, which can be run by his wife. He is requesting a loan to purchase wood and other necessary materials for his business.

About XacBank XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.

To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team: http://www.kiva.org/team/xacbank_mongolia To lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click here:http://www.kiva.org/app.php?page=businesses&queryString=Mongolia&status=fundRaising&gender=All§ors[]=All®ions[]=All&sortBy=Expiring+Soon

loans.use: To purchase wood and other necessary materials for his business.

loans.name: Faaofo

texts.en:
Faaofo M.. is a 49-year-old woman living in the town of Sataua Tai. She is married and has 9 adult children. To make a living, Faaofo owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector, raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting & harvesting taro for sale. loans.name: Myagmar

texts.en:
Myagmar G. is 55 years old and lives with his wife and two youngest children in Uvs province, one of Mongolia's western provinces. His two oldest sons are 19 and 22 years old and are both university students in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. His two youngest daughters go to local secondary schools in Uvs province.

Myagmar retails bags of coals to locals, especially during the cold season when families purchase a lot coal to keep their homes warm. He mostly purchases coal from local mines and resells it to local small businesses and families. As he has been selling coal since 2003, many small business owners and families always purchase their coal from him. He has been a reliable and good supplier of coal for their families and their small businesses.

Although he is already 55 years old, Myagmar is still capable of carrying bags of coal and is happy with his business. He requests a loan to purchase more coal for reselling. 


About XacBank:
XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.
 To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team.
 To lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click here.

loans.name: Alili

texts.en:
Alili F., 58 years old, lives in a poor community in San Miguel Road, Binondo, Manila – a shanty town at the edge of Manila Bay, with her common-law husband Juanito, a fellow vendor, and their two children; one of whom studies in grade school.
 
Alili has been doing business for more than twenty years.  Her sari-sari (general) store has grown steadily through the years.  She also retails rice which she gets in bulk supplies from a government warehouse at discounted price, enabling her to serve many of her marginalized neighbors.  She now earns more than P30,000 in net income per month.  She saves most of her income in preparation for her children’s college education.  At the moment, she is supporting the education of her nephews and nieces.

She joined the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative in 2005.  She has just finished repaying her previous loan with the cooperative so she applied for a new loan in the amount of P50,000 as additional capital for the continuous growth of her business.  She will restock on non-perishable grocery items and rice to sell at her store.

Alili wishes to see her store to grow like a mini-mart or a supermarket someday.  She also dreams of a new house and lot for her family. 



About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice.  This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context.  It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.  CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.name: Piladel

texts.en:
Piladel G. is a 51-year-old married woman who lives in the village of Shopping, Brgy. Fabrica, Sagay City, Negros Occidental. She is engaged in food vending as a source of daily income and raises pigs on the side as a supplement. Her husband Welfredo works as a carpenter. They are blessed with two children who are 15 and 20 years old and still going to school. The younger is in high school and the older attends college. It is Piladel's dream for her children to finish their studies and have a stable income from gainful employment or a stable livelihood, so that they will have a more comfortable life ahead of them.

She thought of going into business to augment her husband's income because she knew that her husband's work could be seasonal at times. And if they relied on only one source of income, she would not be able to fulfill her dreams for her children and their family. At first, she only raised pigs in her backyard, but the return on her investment took 3-4 months to pay off, so she decided to engage in food vending so that she would have a daily income. As her business continued to flourish, she soon needed additional capital to sustain her business operations.

This is why she joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2002. Her loans contributed a lot to increasing their income capacity by allowing them to raise more pigs and increase the variety of food that she sold. Now her minimum monthly income has increased to PHP 2,000 from her food vending operations. And her income from selling the pigs helps to pay for her children's education and provides additional income for their business.

Piladel's previous loan of PHP 19,500 was used as additional working capital for her business. It was fully paid within her loan term without delay. Now she is borrowing her 15th loan in the same amount, PHP 19,500 to be used as additional capital for her pig fattening and food vending businesses. Some of the income will be set aside for her children’s education and to pay for their family expenses. The rest will be plowed back as capital for their business operations.

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional capital for her pig-fattening and food vending businesses

Quyên Ngô Thị's main source of income comes from providing hairdressing and beauty services to members of her community. Quyên (1) is a 34-year-old woman living in the town of T. Hóa. In 2009, Quyên joined T. Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Quyên plans to use the additional revenue to improve the general living conditions of her family.

Quyên is the leader of a four member group accessing a loan offered by T. Hoa Fund for Poor Women. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. loans.name: 02.12.1.1 Nam Ngạn Group

texts.en:
Phượng Lý Thị (1) owns and operates a food stall selling a variety of food products in her community. She is a 47-year-old woman living in the town of Thanh Hóa. Phượng is married and has two grown-up children. Phượng has been in her business for over seven years and earns approximately 1.500.000 dong (VND) a month.

In 2009, Phượng joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Phượng has successfully repaid a previous loan of 1.626.900 VND from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. This previous loan was used to invest in renovating the business. She is requesting a new loan of 6.000.000 VND which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her second loan from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Phượng plans to use the additional revenue to improve the general living conditions of her family.

Phượng is the leader of a four member group accessing a loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is 12.1.1 Nam Ngạn (02.12.1.1).

About the Other Borrowers in the Group: 1. T. Thị Hiền (2) is a 37-year-old woman who is requesting a 6.000.000 VND loan to support her business running a food stall. 2. T. Thị Cảnh (3) is a 38-year-old woman who is requesting a 6.000.000 VND loan to support her business running a food stall. 3. D. Thị Liên (4) is a 28-year-old woman who is requesting a 6.000.000 VND loan to support her business in the manufacturing sector.

About Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women: The mission of Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainable financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in Thanh Hoa province.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

Phượng Lý Thị (1) là 47 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Thanh Hóa. Phượng là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 4 các thành viên. Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ.. Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là 12.1.1 Nam Ngạn (02.12.1.1).

Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ bán các loại thực phẩm khác nhau trong cộng đồng địa phương. Phượng thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 7 năm. Từ các hoạt động này, Phượng kiếm được khoảng 1.500.000 VND. Vào 2009, Phượng đã tham gia Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy. Phượng đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 1.626.900 VND từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng đầu tư đổi mới công việc kinh doanh. Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 6.000.000 VND.

Khoản vay sẽ là 2nd khoản vay của người vay từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.

Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm: 1. T. Thị Hiền (2) là 37 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là buôn bán quầy thực phẩm. 2. T. Thị Cảnh (3) là 38 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là buôn bán quầy thực phẩm. 3. D. Thị Liên (4) là 28 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực sản xuất. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh sản xuất.

Về Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women: Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ vì Phụ Nữ Nghèo Thanh Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh Thanh Hóa.

*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. . Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva. .

texts.en:
Teofilo A. is from the village of Libertad, Aurora, Zamboanga Del Sur. He is 38 years old. Teofilo is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Teofilo operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling charcoal in the local community. Teofilo has been engaged in his business for over two years and earns approximately 8,000 Philippine pesos a month for these activities.

In 2008, Teofilo joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Teofilo is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP, which will also be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the sixth loan taken out by Teofilo from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business.

loans.name: Marcelino

texts.en: This is Marcelino T., a 45-year-old freelance videographer who lives in a fairly large village in San Mateo, Rizal. His wife, Flordeliza, 46, is a freelance writer/editor. They have five adult children of whom three are enrolled in college while the other two are in high school. Marcelino got on-the-job training in videography and video editing from a local broadcast media outfit a few years ago. He has also worked as a writer/editor for different local publications for twelve years. He used these acquired talents in business when he ventured into freelance videography in 2003. This was the start of his career in media services. He began to provide photo/video coverage for his clients until this day. Marcelino has a small studio where he develops photos. He also produces and edits raw video footage which he himself has covered. His net income is now close to P35,000. Marcelino joined the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative in the summer of 2008. The loans provided by the cooperative helped him improve his business for the satisfaction of his clients. Because Marcelino respects the wishes of his clients, he wishes to upgrade his computer so he is able to use more state-of-the-art computer applications to enhance the quality of pictures and videos produced at his studio. To get this done, he applied for a new loan with CCT in the amount of P20,000 for the necessary upgrade of his studio computer. This will be his 6th loan. About CCT The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.

loans.use: To upgrade the computer he uses for photo/video editing

loans.name: Fidela

texts.en:
Fidela A. is from the village of Inroad located in Aurora, a municipality of Zamboanga Del Sur province, Western Mindanao. She is 58 years old, married and has six adult children. Fidela is a tailor who repairs and sells clothes to local businesses and community members. She has been in business for over fifteen years and earns approximately 2,500 PHP a month.

In 2007, Fidela joined GDMPC to gain access to its financial services. She is requesting a loan, her fourth from GDMPC, of 6,000 PHP to be used to buy materials to increase her range of inventory. Fidela successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from GDMPC, which she used to purchase materials to create additional inventory. She plans to use all additional revenue generated from her business to improve her family’s living conditions.

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fishers and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Aquilina

texts.en: Aquilina A. is a native of the island village of Talim, Binangonan, Rizal province in the Philippines. She is 62 years old and wife to Nestor who is 55 years old and is a fisherman. She is blessed with one child, the apple of her eye, named Nestle Ann A., 22 years old, a college student. Aquilina's dream is to uplift their living conditions. She wants to give a decent life to her family, especially her only daughter. She is engaged in a fishing business and has a fish cage where she raises small fish until they grow and are ready for harvest. The business seems to be profitable and sound and she wants to invest more in it. In 2004, Aquilina joined Ahon sa Hirap, Inc., a micro-finance institution and Kiva partner in the Philippines, with the aspiration of having access to capital. She is requesting a loan of Php 25,000 as additional capital for her fish cage. Specifically, the loan will be used to pay for thousands of fingerlings (small fish), one hundred pieces bamboo, sacks of fish food, three rolls of rope, and gasoline for their boat. She will also become engaged in selling RTW (Ready-To-Wear clothes) - assorted clothes for all ages. Aquilina is optimistic that her business will grow and that she can earn more income to save in preparation for her only child’s future, especially her education fees. She also aspires to having more fish cages in order to generate more fish since that means a greater income. She wants also to renovate her fish cage because it was broken in the huge Typhoon Ondoy which was followed by

loans.use: To renovate her fish cage, plus buy RTW clothes for her new business

loans.name: Luisa

texts.en:
Luisa A. is a native of the island village of Talim Binangonan, in the Rizal province of the Philippines. She is a courageous mother who hopes to rise from poverty. She is 62 years old and married to Leon, who is 62 years old and a fisherman. She has 5 children, between the ages of 27 and 43, none of whom finished their studies in college due to poverty. The income from the business has been insufficient to provide for further education for her children beyond high school. 

Luisa's biggest dream is to raise the family's standard of living. She wants to give her family a refined life. She has been in the fishing business for almost 44 years. The sales seem to be profitable and sound, and she desires to invest more in the business.

In 2007, she joined ASHI (Ahon SA Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and KIVA partner in the Philippines, with the encouragement of having access to more capital for a larger income. She is requesting a loan of Php 20,000.00 as additional capital for her fishing business. 

Luisa is hopeful that her business will grow and that she can earn more income.  She would like to save money to help fulfill their dreams to support her children to have a good life and to send her grandchildren to school to finish college, something she failed to provide for her children. Her children are a big support to Luisa and she also believes that her grandchildren are the hopes of their future dreams.

loans.use: purchase of fish nets, ropes, sinkers, bamboo to expand her business

loans.name: Narantuya

texts.en:
Narantuya N. is 43 years old and lives with her husband and three children in Bayanhongor province, one of Mongolia's central provinces. Her two oldest sons (19 and 21 years old) work as draymen at the local market and the 14 year old youngest son goes to a local secondary school. Narantuya's family moved from the countryside where her family used to herd. In the harsh winter of 2003, her family lost many of their livestock and decided to move to their current town in search of a better life for her family. Since the move, she has been doing various small businesses at the local market. She sold cigarettes and offered a wireless phone service for locals. Since July 2009, she has rented a small stall at the market and started selling women and men underwear and other clothing. Her two sons help in her business and, in their free time, they work as draymen for other vendors at the market. She says that she works hard with her two sons to secure a better life for her family. She requests a loan to purchase more products for her business. About XacBank: XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. texts.en:
Venancia B. is from the village of Dimaluna in Ozamiz City. She is 55 years old and married. She has two school-aged children and six adult children. Venancia sells dried fish. She has been engaged in this business for almost a year and earns approximately 2,500 PHP a month.

loans.name: Tungalag

texts.en:
Tungalag S. is a 32 year-old single mother and lives with her 7 year-old son, her mother and younger brother in Bayanhongor province, one of Mongolia's central provinces. Her son is already a student in a local secondary school. Tungalag has done various small businesses to earn income for her family. She used to grow vegetables, grind flour, work in construction and sew traditional clothing for locals. Since 2003, she has been working in construction with her brother during warm seasons. When construction halts during winter, she sews traditional clothing for locals. Her mother taught Tungalag how to sew traditional clothing. She says that she can do any type of job and eventually would like to settle down and do what is best for her and her family. She requests a loan to purchase silk and other necessary materials for her sewing business. About XacBank: XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. texts.en: Tsengel J. is a 21-year-old woman who lives with her parents and two youngest siblings in Bayanhongor Province, one of Mongolia's central provinces. She graduated her high school in 2005. After her high school graduation, she decided to learn how to haircut. She took a training course in haircutting and interned at the local barbershop for a year. She launched her barbershop in 2007 by renting a small space in a local barbershop. As she became recognized by local customers, she decided to move on by herself and opened her own barbershop. She now rents some commercial space and runs her haircutting business. She says that she enjoys running her business and would like to see herself as well as her business to grow fast. She requests a loan to purchase haircutting equipment. About XacBank XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. loans.name: Selenge

texts.en:
Selenge D. graduated from school in 2006 and got just married recently. She is now 32 years old and lives with her husband and 1-year-old daughter in Bayanhongor province, one of Mongolia's central provinces. Her husband currently stays home and takes care of the baby. Selenge used to mine for gold by hand like many locals do at the gold-mining site. She gave up the dirty mining and decided to sell clothes at the local market. Since July 2008, she has been renting a small stall at the local black market and retailing women’s and men’s clothes. She purchases inventory clothes from China, where many of cheap products flood into the country and resells them at her stall. She hopes to expand her business and rent one more stall to sell more clothes. Selenge requests a loan to purchase more inventory for her retail business. About XacBank: XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. Помимо этого он более 15 лет занимается земледелием. В основном он выращивает, овощи. Ему в этом помогают дети. Кредит просит для закупа семян и удобрений.

loans.name: Belen

texts.en:
Mrs. Belen T. is 36 years old. She sells fish, shrimp, and crabs. She’s been in this business for 5 years, starting with capital of PHP 2,000.00. Now she earns an average amount of PHP 5,000.00 per month. Mr. Joel T., her husband, also earns PHP 7,800.00 monthly from his salary as a survey aide for the Ozamiz City local government. They have four school-age children and they reside in San Apolnario, Tangub City. 

Just this year, Mrs. Belen T. joined PAGLAUM MPC. She has no previous loans. With the growth of her loyal customers and market demands, she needs additional capital for her existing fish, crab and shrimp retailing business. She is applying for a first loan of  PHP 20,000.00 to add to her business capital. She will use the profit from this loan for her family's basic needs and for future savings. She is planning to expand her business market in the future.

loans.name: Musyoka

texts.en:
Musyoka K., 49, has been a leathersmith for 21 years.  He began as a shoeshine boy and now runs his own business.  His shop, Iganje Enterprises, is in Mombassa and his leading product is handsewn leather soccer balls.  He sells to schools, stores and individuals.  He also repairs shoes and makes leather covers for bibles.  Musyoka struggles with transport and does not have his own vehicle for marketing his product and delivering his goods.  He also deals with competition from large wholesalers.  He is using this loan to purchase leather, glue and inner tubes for soccer balls for which he has back orders.  He will also re-up his stock of leather soles for shoes.  His ultimate business goal is to have another branch of his shop and multiple employees; he currently has one.

Musyoka is married and has eight children.  He really hopes they will get a good education and become self reliant when they grow up.  He describes himself as talented with high energy and dedication.  He feels the lack of capital is the only thing holding him back from building a larger enterprise

loans.name: Oyunchimeg

texts.en:
D. Oyunchimeg is 47 years old and lives with her two children in Bayanhongor province, Mongolia. She and her family live in a ger, which is a traditional Mongolian housing tent. Her oldest daughter, Tungalag, currently attends university. Oyunchimeg operates a small home repair and interior design business in her town. The business is a collaboration between her and some of her friends. She produces various interior design and home construction items as well as making repairs to heating and cooling lines in homes and apartments. Oyunchimeg started her business in 1998 and has had success over the years. Her earnings have enabled her to support her family and provide for her oldest daughter's tuition fees. Oyunchimeg is very hardworking and hopes to continue to grow her business in the future. She says, "All I want is to educate my children and help them find decent jobs." Oyunchimeg is requesting a 1,000,000 tugrug loan to purchase construction materials for her business and to pay her youngest daughter's tuition fee. About XacBank: XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.

texts.en:
A. Uuganbayar is 28 years old and lives with his wife and two young children in Kharhorin, the capital city of the ancient Mongolian empire. He and his family live in a traditional Mongolian housing tent called a "ger". His wife is currently employed as an accountant at a local grocery shop.
Uuganbayar operates a transportation service in his town using his large van. He transports people to and from Kharhorin and Ulaanbaatar, the largest city and capital of Mongolia. Uuganbayar started his business in 2003 after working as a livestock herder for three years. He has found success with his business over the years and has built up a reputation as a good and honest driver. Uuganbayar is focused on continuing to improve his business and provide a good life for his family. He hopes to use his earnings to buy a new house for them. Uuganbayar is requesting a 1,500,000 MNT loan to purchase a new motor and heating system for his van. The picture shows Uuganbayar with his youngest child.

About XacBank
XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.
To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team.
To lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click here.

loans.use: To purchase a new motor and heating system for his van

loans.name: Altanbold

texts.en:
J. Altanbold is 37 years old and lives with his wife and son in Kharhorin, which is the capital city of the ancient Mongolian empire. He and his family live in a traditional Mongolian housing tent called a "ger". His son is 14 years old and currently attends a local secondary school. Altanbold operates a grocery, meat and raw materials trading business in his town with the help of his wife. His wife is responsible for managing the grocery business and Altanbold takes care of the meat and raw materials selling. He purchases his products from herders in the countryside and uses his truck to transport them back to town to sell. The couple went into business in 1996 after moving to Kharhorin from the countryside. At first they only had a small shipping container where they ran the grocery business, but after growing their business and saving some money they expanded and now rent a stall at a large trading center. Altanbold hopes to continue his success in the future and says, "My wife and I are working hard to save money for our son's education." He is requesting a 3,000,000 tugrug loan to purchase meat and raw materials for his business. About XacBank: XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.
To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team.
To lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click here.

loans.use: To purchase more meat and raw materials

loans.name: Banzragch

texts.en:
N. Banzragch is 34 years old and lives with his wife and two sons in Zavhan province in western Mongolia. He and his family live in a ger, which is a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. Both of his sons, aged four and two, are in kindergarten. Banzragch operates a business making wooden products in his town. He designs and produces a variety of wooden furniture with the help of his brother. He started his business in 2007 after working as a carpenter for a private company for two years. Using his experience, Banzragch and his brother have built a stable business over the past two years, and their many customers are very satisfied with the quality items they produce. As a young, business-minded entrepreneur, Banzragch has developed a good taste in making unique and stylish furniture that is in demand. He is focused on the future and has plans to soon hire two assistants to increase his production capacity. He says, " I want to improve my business so I can buy a house for my family." Banzragch is requesting a 1,000,000 tugrug loan to purchase wood, glue, lacquer and other necessary materials for his business. About XacBank: XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.
To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team.
To lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click here.

loans.use: To purchase wood, glue, lacquer and other necessary materials

loans.name: Francis

texts.en:
Francis is a 25-year-old married man with a 3-year-old son. He describes himself as a mature and aggressive businessman that is trustworthy and innovative. He owns two retail clothing stores, from which he sells men's jeans and shirts. On a daily basis, he runs one of these stores, while his wife runs the other shop across town. From this business, Francis generates approximately 30,000 KES per month.

Francis explains that he started his business two years ago with a loan from Equity Bank. He was able to obtain this loan because he was a salaried employee working in accounting. When he left his accounting job, he opted for a loan from KADET to help him improve his business. With this loan that he is seeking, Francis will purchase new jeans and shirts to sell in his clothing shops. He only buys one of each style so that he can keep his merchandise unique, which he thinks draws customers to his stores. In the future, Francis hopes to open a large retail shop and to import specialty men's clothing.

About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients. Specifically, KADET provides financial services to its members, thereby improving living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the micro-finance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the following website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To expand his business by purchasing new men's jeans and shirts to sell in his clothing shop

loans.name: Bayarhuu

texts.en:
Bayarhuu Shagparsuren is a 47-year-old married man, living with his wife and two children in the Zavkhan province of western Mongolia. He and his family live in a ger, which is a traditional Mongolian housing tent. His oldest son, Lhamsuren, is a college student, and his youngest, Banzragch, is in high school.

Bayarhuu operates a wood product-making business in his town as a partnership with a few of his friends. He mainly produces wood items which are used in ger construction and traditional ger furniture. His business is very popular and his customer base includes both residents of his province as well as two other adjoining provinces. Bayarhuu started his business in 1999, and he has made much progress over the years. He is a savvy businessman, and he is constantly looking for ways to improve his operations. For example, because many countryside people, who are his main customers, often lack sufficient cash to purchase his products, he instead trades with them; more specifically, he might trade his wood items for flour, which he would then sell in his town for a profit. Bayarhuu has used his business' success to build a workshop and to provide a quality life for his family. He says, "I want my children to be educated people and to have a good life. I am working hard to support them." He has many plans for the future, such as expanding his workshop and hiring two new assistants. By doing so, he will be able to expand his production capacity and to begin producing a wider variety of unique and stylish furniture. Bayarhuu is requesting a loan in the amount of 700,000 tugrug (approximately $500 USD) to purchase wood and materials for his business.

About XacBank: XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest micro-finance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale, and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save. To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team at http://www.kiva.org/team/xacbank_mongolia. To lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click here: http://www.kiva.org/app.php?page=businesses&queryString=Mongolia&status=fundRaising&gender=All§ors[]=All®ions[]=All&sortBy=Expiring+Soon

loans.use: To expand his business by purchasing additonal wood

loans.name: Jaahuu

texts.en:
Jaahuu G. is a 43-year-old married man, living with his wife and 6-year-old son in the Uvurkhangai province of Mongolia. He and his family live in a ger, which is a traditional Mongolian housing tent. His son currently attends a local secondary school.

With his wife's assistance, Jaahuu operates a consumer goods trading business and a small cafe in his town. More specifically, Jaahuu manages the consumer goods business, while his wife is responsible for running the cafe. Jaahuu and his wife started their food cafe in 2002. After several years of successful operations, he used his savings to start his consumer goods business in 2009. In particular, he imports products from China, such as clothing, twice per month to re-sell to local customers. He and his wife are very hardworking people, and they attribute their success to their good communication skills. Jaahuu has many plans for the future, and he hopes to grow his new business. He says, "My goal is to expand and maintain both of our businesses." He is requesting a loan in the amount of 1,500,000 tugrug (approximately, $1,050 USD) to import additional clothes from China for his consumer goods business.

loans.use: To expand his business by importing additional clothes

loans.name: Myagmarsuren

texts.en:
G. Myagmarsuren is 29 years old and lives with his wife and 2-year-old son in Uvurkhangai province, Mongolia. He and his family live in a ger, which is a traditional Mongolian housing tent. His wife is currently employed as a cook at a café. Myagmarsuren operates a taxi service in his town. He started his business in 2007 and has had success in his first two years of operation. Today he is well established among the many taxi drivers and has a good reputation as a driver. Myagmarsuren's business is important to him and he works hard to support his family. He says, "I want my brother to be able to finish college. I will do my best to support him." Myagmarsuren is requesting a 1,000,000 tugrug (~700 USD) loan to purchase machinery parts for his car and to assist in paying his brother's tuition fees.

About XacBank XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva's 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save. To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team: http://www.kiva.org/team/xacbank_mongolia

loans.use: Purchase machinery parts for his car

loans.name: Batdorj

texts.en:
S. Batdorj is 25 years old and lives with his wife and infant son in Zavkhan province in western Mongolia. He and his family live in a ger, which is a traditional Mongolian housing tent. His wife is currently unemployed and watches after 1-year-old Batstooj. Batdorj operates a meat and dairy trading business in his town. His work is seasonal as he sells meat mainly in the spring months and dairy products in the winter. Batdorj started his business in 2008 and has made progress in his first year of operation. As the winter months are quickly approaching, he is currently busy prepping his dairy business for a successful season. Batdorj is a very hardworking entrepreneur and has very good character. He is focused on growing his business in the future and providing a quality life for his new son. He recently used his earnings to begin construction on a new house for his family. Batdorj is requesting a 705,000 tugrug (~496 USD) loan to purchase dairy products to sell this winter season.



About XacBank
XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.

To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team: http://www.kiva.org/team/xacbank_mongolia

loans.use: To purchase dairy products

loans.name: Mendbayar

texts.en:
L. Mendbayar is 39 years old and lives with her two daughters in Bayanhongor province, Mongolia. She and her children live together in a ger, which is a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. Her oldest daughter is 19 years old and in college, and her youngest, age 10, attends a local secondary school. Mendbayar operates a meat trading business out of a rented stall at a local market in her town. She started her business in 2002 and has made much progress over the years. This past year she expanded her business by purchasing a field and growing her own vegetables to sell.  It was a good year as she harvested over 400 kg of potatoes, 200 kg of beets, and 300 kg of cabbage. Mendbayar hopes to build on her recent success and expand her business further. She hopes to build a small grocery shop for her products in teh near future. Her business is very important to her and she says, "All I want is to support my children's education and to own my own grocery shop." She is requesting a 560,000 tugrug (~394 USD) loan to purchase meat for her business.



About XacBank
XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.

To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team: http://www.kiva.org/team/xacbank_mongolia

loans.use: To purchase raw meat for her business

loans.name: Odontungalag

texts.en:
D. Odontungalag is 31 years old and lives with her two children in Bayanhongor province, Mongolia. She and her two children live in a ger, which is a traditional Mongolian housing tent. Her oldest son currently attends a local secondary school and her youngest daughter is only two years old. Odontungalag operates a small clothing production business in her town with the help of her relatives. Her business is especially busy during the winter and also during the wedding season in Mongolia. She produces a variety of warm traditional Mongolian clothes during the winter and makes beautiful dresses for the many brides during the warmer months of the year.

Odontungalag started her business in 1998 and has built a stable operation over the years. At first she had only manual sewing machines but has used her earnings to purchase 2 electric sewing machines. She has gained much experience as a businesswoman over the years and has improved her skills as a seamstress. Her business has provided financial security for her family and has enabled her to provide for her children's education. Odontungalag is focuses on the future and hopes to continue to grow her business. She says, "This coming winter is going to be an especially cold one. For that reason, I plan to produce warm Mongolian traditional shoes in addition to clothes." Odontungalag is requesting a 500,000 tugrug (~350 USD) loan to purchase materials used in making traditional shoes. About XacBank XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save. To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team: http://www.kiva.org/team/xacbank_mongolia

loans.use: To purchase materials used in making traditional shoes.

loans.name: Gouye Gui 2 Group

texts.fr: Le Groupement Gouye Gui est composé de femmes très dynamiques qui travaillent dans l'achat vente de poissons .Généralement les maris sont des pécheurs et à leur retour de la mer ils donnent une partie aux femmes pour la gestion de leur quotidien et ces dernières achètent avec leur moyen pour le renforcement de leur activité . ce prêt va contribuer à l'achat de produits halieutiques et d'avoir une certaine autonomie vis à vis de leur maris.
texts.en:
