Con este préstamo de S/. 2,000.00, comprará repuestos y aceites como: lubricantes, bocamasas, bujías; para así brindar un mejor servicio y atender mucho mejor al cliente.

Besilia, se siente muy bien al pertenecer a un grupo de mujeres, que le ha ayudado a conocer mejor sus derechos y juntas  hacer que estas sean respetadas. Y agradece bastante al Movimiento Manuela Ramos, por ayudarla a iniciarse en el campo empresarial.
texts.en:
Señora Besilia is a member of the communal bank "10 de Agosto II," located in the Tarapoto district of San Martin province in the San Martin region. She is 23 years old, lives with a partner and is the mother of 2 children, both of whom are dependent on her as they are in school. Besilia is a hardworking woman who has always been characterized by an optimistic spirit. For 6 years she has had an urban passenger transport business using her motocar (light, 3-wheeled passenger vehicle). Her partner does the driving, taking the motocar to different places in the city. Little by little, she was saving and with this money she was buying spare parts in order to improve the service to the residents of the city. With this loan of 2,000 nuevos soles, she will buy spare parts and oils such as: lubricants, wheel hubs and spark plugs, so that she can provide better service and meet the needs of her customers. Besilia feels great about belonging to a group of women who have helped her to better understand her rights, and who together have managed to become better respected. She is also very grateful to the Manuela Ramos Movement organization for helping her to start out in business.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: she will buy spare parts for her motocar

loans.name: Ailen

texts.es:
La señora Ailen, pertenece al Banco Comunal “10 de Agosto II”, Distrito de Tarapoto, Provincia de San Martin, Departamento de San Martín,  Es Conviviente, tiene 26 años y es madre de  01 hijo, que aun depende de ella y están estudiando.

Ailen, lleva 10 años dedicándose a la confección de vestidos, ya que teniendo conocimiento en este tipo de actividad, no dudo en implementar su propio taller de costura, ubicada en su misma casa, en un ambiente muy bien acondicionado, donde diariamente atiende a sus clientes fijos, que ya la conocen y necesitan el servicio. Trabaja con pedidos que con anticipación sus clientes le solicitan. En la actualidad, continua con el mismo negocio y se siente muy contenta y orgullosa por lo logrado. 

Con el préstamo de S/. 800.00, comprará telas en metros, de diferentes especies y colores, instrumentos que utiliza como tijeras, hilos en carretes grande y de variados colores, agujas de coser y de maquina, alfileres, botones. 

Hoy en día se siente una mujer muy realizada, con más ganas de alcanzar y hacer realidad sus demás sueños. Agradece al Movimiento Manuela Ramos por ayudarla a iniciar su negocio y también a muchas mujeres que  quieren crecer empresarialmente.
texts.en:
Señora Ailen belongs to the communal bank, "10 de Agosto II" in the district of Tarapoto, in the province of San Martín, in the department of San Martín. She has a live-in boyfriend, is 26, and has one son who is still her dependent and goes to school. She has made dresses for 10 years since she is knowledgeable about this activity. She didn't have any doubts about implementing her own sewing shop, which is located in her home. It is fixed up nicely, and she attends to her fixed clientele here daily. They know her and need her service. She works by taking orders that her customers request from her with anticipation. Currently, she is continuing with her business and feels vey happy and proud about what she has acheived. With this loan for 800 PEN, she will purchase fabric by the meter in different colors and tools that she uses like scissors, thread in large spools in different colors, sewing needles, pins, and buttons. Today she feels like a very accomplished woman with more desires to reach and make her dreams a reality. She is thankful to Manuela Ramos for helping her start her business as well as many other women who want to grow their businesses.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: She will purchase sewing supplies

loans.name: Dreu

texts.en: Mrs. Dreu D. is from the village of Sulipat, Calamba, Misamis Occidental. She is 37 years old, is married, and is blessed with three school-aged children. Dreu owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) store selling of variety of food products in the local community. She earns 3,000 PHP monthly from her business. In 2003, Dreu joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC. She is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP which will be used as additional capital for her business. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her sari-sari store

loans.name: Richard

texts.en:
Richard is 31 years old and married. He sells fruit and vegetables. He's been in business for two years and has two employees. He also earns some income as the caretaker for the Parklands SDA Church. He requested this loan for Kes. 40,000 to buy exotic fruits like apples and imported oranges.

Richard describes himself as mature and stable and says that since he became a member of Faulu his business has improved especially because he keeps records. In the future, he hopes to continue to grow his business and become a direct importer of exotic fruits.

loans.use: Buy exotic fruits

loans.name: Richard

texts.en:
Richard is 37 years old, married, and has three school-age children: two daughters and a son. He runs a welding business and has been in business since 1997. He also earns some income from small-scale farming. He says that his business is competitive and busy. He successfully repaid a previous loan from Faulu for 20,000 Kenyan shillings and requested this loan for 40,000 Kenyan shillings to purchase gauges, pipes, and rods for welding.

He describes himself as obedient, hardworking, and patient with customers and says that since he became a member of Faulu he has opened a savings account. In the future, he hopes to open a big garage and employ staff.

loans.use: Purchase gauges, pipes & welding rods

loans.name: Philemon

texts.en:
Philemon is 35 years old. He runs a small retail business selling spare auto parts and paint. He's been in business for five years and has one employee. He successfully repaid a previous loan from Faulu for Kes. 20,000 and requested this loan for Kes. 40,000 to add stock and expand his business premises.

He describes himself as social and very hardworking and says that since he became a member of Faulu he has diversified his business and his income has increased. In the future, he hopes to invest in the stock market and real estate.

loans.use: Add to his stock of paints

loans.name: Sabitri

texts.en:
Mrs. Sabitri M., 29, lives in Thecho, Nepal, with her husband and a daughter. Her husband, Dharma lal M., works in Nepal Telecom as a field worker, and her daughter is studying in grade 1. 
Mrs. M. opened a wood shop six years ago. She is a very hard-working woman and does all her work perfectly. She is a wood dealer and supplies wood to a local carpentry shop, which makes windows, doors and other items. Now she is requesting a loan of Rs 25000.00 to purchase more wood to fulfill the demands of the local markets. 
Mrs. M. wants to save money for the future and be able to afford further study for her daughter.

loans.use: To buy more timber

loans.name: Tari Mai

texts.en: Mrs. Tari Mai M. lives in Thecho Village. Thecho is located in the Lalitpur district. Thecho is one of the developing village of Lalitpur and most of the people in this region are engaged in agricultural farming. Tarimai M. lives in a single family with her husband and one son. Her son is studying in grade 8. Both Mrs. M. and her husband, Mr. Aananda M., are engaged in making brass religious statues. They make different types of statues according to the orders they get. They fulfill all the needs of the family with the income from their work making statues. Now Mrs. M. is requesting a loan of Rs 30000.00 to buy different types of raw materials to use for brass religious statues.

loans.use: To buy raw materials for her work

loans.name: Dus Maiya

texts.en:
Mrs. Dus Maiya M., a resident of Thecho, lives in a nuclear family with her husband and two children. Her daughter and son are studying in grades 6 and 3, respectively. 


Mrs. Dus Maiya M. and her husband, Mr. Nucha M., are both engaged in idol making. They make different types of traditional gods' idols. They make idols according to the demands of their customers. Nowadays in their area, the demand for idols is increasing so to meet the demand, they need to invest funds in their business. But due to lack of funds, they are unable to meet the demands of their customers. So Mrs. M. is requesting a loan of Rs 20000.00 to buy raw materials like wax, silver, bronze, etc. for their business.

loans.use: To buy raw materials for her work

loans.name: Elkanah

texts.en:
Elkanah is 27 years old and has a livestock farming business in the Kiambu area of Nairobi. He sells milk and poultry meat and has two employees. He also earns some income through small-scale maize farming and a matatu (taxi van) business. He previously worked in the IT department at Safaricom. He describes himself as young and ambitious.

He requested this loan from Faulu for Kes. 40,000 to purchase chicks for poultry farming and feed for the cows and chicks. In the future, he hopes to buy more land for farming.

loans.use: To purchase chicks & animal feeds

loans.name: Narayan Devi

texts.en:
Mrs. Narayan Devi M., 33, lives in Thecho, Lalitpur, Nepal. Thecho is one of the beautiful, underdeveloped villages of Nepal. Most of the people of this region are poor and depend on agriculture to make a living. 

Mrs. M. has two children, a daughter and a son. Both her children are studying in grade 7.

Mrs. M. opened a grocery shop four years ago. She sells different types of grocery items such as rice, maize, pulses (legumes), biscuits and noodles in her shop. Her children also help her in her work. The demand for grocery goods is increasing in her area, so she is requesting a loan of NPR 30,000 to buy grocery items to meet the demand.

loans.use: To buy grocery goods

loans.name: Viota

texts.en:
Viota is 33 years old and married with two children. She has a business supplying sausages, bacon, beef brawn (cured, cooked, smoked and ready-to-eat beef) and Famer's Choice meat products as well as clothing. She's been in business for three years and is now requesting a loan for Kes. 30,000 to purchase stock of clothes, handbags and more Farmer's Choice products.

She describes herself as reliable and focused and says that since she joined Faulu she has been more independent. In the future, she would like to improve her standard of living by expanding her business and putting up her own stall in the central business district of Nairobi.

loans.use: Add stock

loans.name: Asha

texts.en:
Mrs. Asha M., a resident of Tangal, lives in a nuclear family with her husband and one child. Her husband's name is Shyam M. and he is a house painter. Her daughter is studying in grade 2.


Mrs. M.'s family's living conditions are miserable, as her husband’s work is not permanent. Sometimes he may not get a job for a month. So they can hardly fulfill their basic needs. They can’t send their child to boarding school.



So to overcome this problem, Mrs. M. decided to open a momo (meat dumplings) shop. But due to lack of money, she is unable to open her shop. So Mrs. M. is requesting her second loan of Rs 15,000.00 to open the momo shop.

loans.use: To buy ingredients to make products to sell

loans.name: Laxmi

texts.en:
Laxmi B. lives in Tangal. Tangal is located in the Lalitpur district. Tangal is one of the busy bazaars of Lalitpur and most of the people in this region are engaged in handicraft work.
Mrs. Laxmi lives in a single family with her husband and two sons. Both her sons are now studying as well as working.
Both Mrs. B. and Mr. B. are engaged in wood carving work. They carve different types of wooden goods. They run their house with the income from their wood carving work.
Now Mrs. B. is requesting a loan of Rs 10,000.00 to buy wood and tools to use in their wood carving work.

loans.use: To buy wood and tools

loans.name: Man Maiya

texts.en:
Mrs. Man Maiya L. is a resident of Tangal. Tangal is located in the Lalitpur district and most of the people in this region are engaged in handicraft work.
Mrs. Man Maiya L. lives with her husband and two daughters. Her husband, Mr. Bir Bahadur L., is a driver. Both her daughters are studying in pre-primary school.
Mrs. L. opened her small restaurant a few years ago to strengthen the economic condition of her family. In her restaurant, she makes Nepali food (dalbhat) for her customers. She also serves tea and coffee to the customers. Now she is requesting a loan of Rs 20,000.00 to buy food items for her business.

loans.use: To buy food items for her business

loans.name: Anju

texts.en:
Anju L. is a 24 year-old woman who lives in Tangal, Lalitpur. She lives with her husband and one son. Her husband is a driver and her son is in pre-primary school.

Mrs L. is a shopkeeper. Mrs L. opened her grocery shop two years ago to increase the quality of life of her family. She sells a variety of grocery items. She wants to further expand her business so she is requesting a Rs 20,000.00 loan to buy necessary grocery items for her shop.

loans.use: To buy grocery goods

loans.name: Francis

texts.en:
Francis is 26 years old and married with one young child. He has a business in the Kayole area of Nairobi buying and selling electronics, such as televisions, DVDs, and MEKOs (gas cookers). He's been in this business for two years and employs one person. He also earns income distributing kerosene. 

He requested this loan for 80,000 KES from Faulu to purchase more electronics to sell. He describes himself as stable and focused and says that since he became a member of Faulu he has been able increase his overall income. In the future, he hopes to open more branches of his business.

loans.use: Add to stock of electronics

loans.name: Ram Devi

texts.en:
Ram Devi Tamarkar is 43 years old and lives in the Tangal region of Nepal. She is married and lives with her husband and their two sons. She works alongside her husband in their small hotel, which they opened together ten years ago.

Because the number of customers frequenting her hotel has increased in recent years, Ram is seeking a loan of 30,000 NPR to purchase materials for improving the quality of the hotel.

She hopes to use the profits generated by this loan to increase the value of their house and also to provide a better education for their children.

loans.use: to buy materials to improve the quality of their hotel

loans.name: Thomas

texts.en: Thomas is 32 years old and married with one child. He has a garbage collection business and employs four people. He's been in this business for five years and also works as a carpet cleaner. He describes himself as organized and hardworking, and says that he hopes to expand his clientele outside of Nairobi. He requested this loan from the Kiva Partner, Faulu, for 80,000 KES to buy a truck to transport garbage.

loans.use: to buy a truck for transporting garbage

loans.name: Sumitra

texts.en:
Mrs. Sumitra R. lives in Kulashwor, which is located in the Kathmandu district, and most of the people in the region are engaged in small business.

Sumitra lives in a single family home with her husband and three children. She has two sons and one daughter. Both her sons are studying in high school and her daughter is in lower secondary school.

She opened her vegetable shop a year ago to raise her family's standard of living. She sells green vegetables in her shop. Sumitra utilizes her income to provide education for her children.

loans.use: to buy vegetables to sell

loans.name: Dolores

texts.en: Dolores P. is from the village of Gango, Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidental. She is 55 years old, is married, and has two school-aged and four adult children. Dolores owns and operates a business planting and harvesting corn for sale. She has been engaged in her business for over twenty years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month. In 2004, Dolores joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 25,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. Dolores is requesting a new loan of 50,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizer such as manure. This will be her 9th loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer such as manure

loans.name: Ma. Teresa

texts.en: Mrs. Ma.Teresa P. is from the village of Lucos, Sapang Dalaga, Misamis Occidental. She is 39 years old, is married, and is blessed with four school-aged children. Ma. Teresa owns and operates a business selling lumber for construction in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for more than five years earning 4,000 PHP net monthly. In 2007, Ma. Teresa joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC. Ma. Teresa is requesting a new loan of 14,900 PHP which will be used as additional capital for her business. This loan will be her 8th from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her business

loans.name: Florence Mutyaba ‘S Group

texts.en: Florence is a 42-year-old married woman with four children between 10 and 20 years of age.  All her children go to school. She rents a two-room house where she is staying with four people. Florence takes care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity but no piped water and gets three meals a day. She incurs transport costs to and from buying second hand clothes from Owino market, one of the busiest markets in Uganda. She pays rent for both her business and residence.  She works in a semi-urban area, which is on the outskirts of Kampala. She works six days a week. She receives an average of 10 customers a day and sells to all categories of people, at both retail and wholesale. Besides this second hand clothes business, she does tailoring for both new and torn clothes.  Her greatest monthly expenses include feeding the family and school fees for her children. Her major business challenges are transportation and the rainy season because she works in an open place. She has been in this business for eight years and with MCDT for eight years servicing her 13th loan, working with the same group mates. Florence joined MCDT because it was near her home and was working with poor women. She wants to use this loan to buy more bales of second hand clothes and materials for tailoring. She is hoping to see her business grower bigger and start selling wholesale only.

loans.use: To buy more bales of second hand clothes

loans.name: Lukia

texts.en: Lukia is a 47-year-old married woman with five children between 10 and 20 years of age. All her children go to school. She owns a three-room house where she is staying with three people. Lukia doesn’t take care of additional family members. The family has no access to electricity but has piped water and gets three meals a day. She incurs transport costs to and from buying new and second hand clothes at Owino market, one of the busiest markets in Uganda. She doesn’t pay rent for her business.  She works in a semi-urban area, which is on the outskirts of Kampala, because she moves door to door selling her clothes. She works seven days a week. She receives an average of 10 customers a day and sells to all categories of people at both retail and wholesale.  Her greatest monthly expenses include feeding the family and school fees for her children. Her major business challenges are transportation and the rainy season, which hinders her to reach her customers. She has been in this business for 10 years and with MCDT for 12 years, servicing her 30th loan working with the same group mates. Lukia joined MCDT because it was near her home and was working with poor women. She wants to use this loan to buy more bales of second hand clothes and new clothes. She is hoping to see her business grower bigger, start selling wholesale only and getting a permanent business premise.

loans.use: To buy bales of used and new clothes

loans.name: Sanilyn

texts.en:
Sanilyn is a 36-year-old married woman from Agusan Del Sur. She has seven children with her husband Richard. Her oldest child is now 17.

Sanilyn is a rice farmer. She spends most of her time taking care of the farm. She wants to ensure its good condition. The farm is her only source of income, so she works hard to achieve an abundant harvest.

She joined CEVI, a Kiva field partner, to use its financial services, which is what Sanilyn really needs. She requested a loan of 15,000 PHP. This loan will be used to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm supplies. She will also use part of it to pay the laborers who helped at her farm.

loans.use: to buy farm supplies and pay laborers

loans.name: Joan

texts.en:
31-year-old Joan is the mother of two. She has been married for seven years. Joan’s business is rice farming. She shared that her business is productive now and hopes to maintain it this way.

A member of the Kiva field partner, CEVI, for three years now, she can say that its program is really helpful to farmers like her. She is currently asking for a loan of 15,000 PHP. She will use this loan to buy gasoline for her tractor and to acquire farm supplies needed at her farm. This loan will help sustain Joan’s business.

loans.use: Farm Supplies

loans.name: Jaime

texts.en:
Jaime tills his 1-hectare rice field with diligence. At 52, he is still strong enough to manage his farm. He is married and has four kids. His oldest child is now 27 years old.

Jaime shared that his farm needs financing, which is something he cannot provide right now. He sought the help of CEVI, an MFI (micro-finance institution) in the Philippines and also a KIVA field partner. He asked for a loan of 14,000 PHP. With this loan, Jaime will be able to buy fertilizers and other farm supplies he needs.

loans.use: Fertilizers and other farm supplies

loans.name: Jaime

texts.en:
Mr. Jaime E. works hard for his family. He is married and has four children. His oldest child is only 9 years old.

He started farming in 2006. He cultivates his land for rice crops. Aside from farming, he also raises pigs to have another source of income. Jaime has been a member of CEVI, a Kiva field partner, for three years now. He said that its program has really helped him a lot in his business. He is now requesting a loan of 12,000 PHP.

He will use this loan to buy crude oil for his tractor, farm supplies, and also to pay the laborers who help at his farm.

loans.use: to buy farm supplies and to pay laborers

loans.name: Julie

texts.en:
Mr. Julie A. has been married to Ruth since 2004. Their four-year-old child adds joy to his little family. He wants to make a happy home and to save for his child’s future.

To provide income for the family, he ventured into rice farming. He tills his farm with patience. Julie also shared that he is in need of financial assistance for his farm. He asked to borrow 12,000 PHP. He will use this loan to purchase seeds, fertilizers and farm supplies. This loan will also help Julie save for his child’s future.

loans.use: Farm supplies, seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Aisha Kabuye‘S Group

texts.en: Aisha is a 40-year-old married woman with six children between the ages of 6 and 20 years.  All her children go to school. She rents a two-room house where she is staying with three people. Aisha doesn’t take care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity but no piped water and gets three meals a day.  Aisha owns a beauty salon in Nakulabye Kiyaye zone. She incurs transport costs to and from buying hair conditioners and hair extensions from Kikuubo shops, one of the busiest places in Kampala city. She pays rent for her business premises at 45000/= per month.  She works in a semi-urban area, which is on the outskirts of Kampala. She works seven days a week. She receives an average of seven customers a day and works on all categories of people, whether its relaxing, braiding or plaiting.  Her greatest monthly expenses include feeding the family and school fees for her children. Her major business challenges are transportation and the rainy season, which hinders her customers from reaching her. She has been in this business for nine years and with MCDT for five years, servicing her 10th loan, working with the same group mates. Aisha joined MCDT because it was near her home and was working with poor women. She wants to use this loan to buy more boxes of cream relaxers, hair conditioners and hair extensions. She is hoping to see her business grower bigger, start doing manicures and pedicures only, and getting a permanent business premise.

loans.use: To buy hair conditioners and hair extensions

loans.name: Beverly

texts.en:
Mrs. Beverly P. enjoys taking care of her rice farm. She is 45 years old, married and has two children. She said that her business is very helpful to her family. It provides their daily needs and enables her to pay her bills.

Beverly’s farm currently needs additional farm supplies like fertilizers. She applied for a loan from the Kiva field partner, CEVI, in the amount of 15,000 PHP. Receiving this loan will be truly helpful to Beverly as she works to have an abundant harvest.

loans.use: Farm supplies

loans.name: Mary Jean

texts.en: Mary Jean is a farmer. She is 42 years old and married. She has two children and her oldest is only 15. She cultivates rice on her land, which is one of the major agricultural crops in her town in Agusan del Sur. Mary Jean is a member of Community Economic Ventures, Inc. Her previous loan was used for farm financing, and she was also able to acquire 4 pigs. Now, she is requesting a loan of 10,000 PHP, which she will use to purchase necessary farm supplies. She is hopeful that this loan will help her farm and pig-raising business grow.

loans.use: Farm supplies

loans.name: Peninah

texts.en: Peninah is a 35-year-old married woman with four children between 10 and 16 years of age.  All her children go to school. She rents a three-room house where she is staying with eight people. Peninah takes care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity but no piped water and gets three meals a day.  She incurs transport costs to and from buying clothing materials from Kampala city and uses public transport to and from shopping. She works in a semi-urban area, which is on the outskirts of Kampala. Peninah works six days a week .She receives an average of six customers a day and sells to all categories of people. She pays monthly rent of 50000/= for her business. Her major business challenges are the increasing price of clothing materials and the rainy season, which hinders her customers from reaching her.  Peninah has been in this business for eight years and with MCDT for five years, servicing her 14th loan. She wants to use this loan to buy more rolls of clothing material. She hopes to see her business grow and start designing bridal gowns.

loans.use: To buy more rolls of fabric

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en: Lucy, 43 years old, farms rice for a living. She is married and has four children. Her oldest child is now 24 years old. She used to borrow from individuals who charged high interest. She was not able to save because of it. When she heard of CEVI, she immediately joined and was fortunate to qualify as a member. She is now requesting a loan of 15,000 PHP. She will use this loan to buy seeds, fertilizers, and other farm supplies. She will also buy gasoline for her tractor. This loan will help Lucy finance her farm, and she will also be able to save because of the loan interest offered at CEVI.

loans.use: Farm supplies

loans.name: Cesario

texts.en: 47-year-old Cesario is a diligent farmer. He has been married to Clara for 18 years, and they are blessed with four children. Farming is tedious work, but Cesario loves it nonetheless. He makes sure to rid his farm of weeds and other pests. He is now preparing his rice field for planting. He applied for a loan from CEVI amounting to 15,000 PHP. With this loan, Cesario will be able to buy seeds, fertilizers, and other farm supplies to be used at his farm.

loans.use: Farm supplies

loans.name: Enriqueta

texts.en: Enriqueta, 33 years old, has three children with her husband, Jonito. Her oldest child is only 6 years old. Like any mother, she wants her children to have a proper education and to improve her family’s living conditions. She invested in rice farming. She also joined CEVI, not just to avail of its financial services, but also to develop her business skills. She requested a loan of 15,000 PHP, which she will use for seeds, fertilizers, and other farm supplies. She will also buy gasoline for her tractor. This loan will help Enriqueta start saving up for her children’s future.

loans.use: Farm supplies

loans.name: Aisha

texts.en:
Aisha is a 36 year old married woman, with four children aged between 10 and 16. All her children go to school. She resides and owns a three room house where she lives with four people. Aisha takes care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity and piped water and gets three meals a day.

Aisha works in a semi urban area on the outskirts of Kampala. She incurs transportation costs traveling to and from the African Village along Buganda Road in Kampala city to buy merchandise and uses public transport to and from shopping. Aisha works six days a week. She receives an average of twenty customers a day and sells to all categories of people. She pays a monthly rent of 45000 UGX. Her major business challenges are the increasing prices of crafts and transportation. She has been in this business for fifteen years and with MCDT for five years, servicing her eleventh loan. Aisha wants to use this loan to buy more merchandise for crafts for her retail shop. She hopes to see her business grow bigger and to start selling wholesale only.

loans.use: To buy more crafts for resale

loans.name: Mary Joy

texts.en: Mrs. Mary Joy E. is a resident of Sta. Josefa, Agusan del Sur. She is 34 years old, married, and has four children. Her oldest child is only 16 years old. She invested in rice farming. She plants rice because it is a necessity among Filipinos. She currently needs additional capital for her farm. She applied to CEVI and asked to borrow 15,000 PHP. With this loan, Mary Joy will be able to finance her farm and, in turn, sustain her family’s needs.

loans.use: Farm supplies

loans.name: Virgincita

texts.en: Virgincita does not let her age hinder her in doing what she loves. She is 60 years old and is still strong enough to do farming duties. She tills a hectare of rice field. She shared that her farm currently needs financial support. She applied to Community Economic Ventures, Inc. to gain access to loan services. She requested a loan of 15,000 PHP, which she will use to buy fertilizers and other farm supplies needed at her farm to grow.

loans.use: Farm supplies

loans.name: Herminia

texts.en: 49-year-old Herminia farms rice for a living. She is married and has 9 children. Her oldest is only 20 years old. Having a big family, she works extra hard to provide for their daily needs. She makes sure her farm is in the best condition so that it can produce quality harvests and thus sustain her family. She sought the help of CEVI to assist her financially. Her previous loans were used to finance her farm. She is now requesting a loan of 15,000 PHP. This loan will be used for farming supplies such as gasoline for the tractor, seeds, fertilizers, and other farm supplies for the farm. Receiving this loan is really helpful to Herminia and her family.

loans.use: Farm supplies

loans.name: Lolita

texts.en: Rice farming is Lolita’s source of income. At 41, she is married and has 6 children. She has children who are in college now, and Lolita works hard to sustain her kids’ education. To gain access to financial services, she joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc., an MFI in the Philippines. She also wants to improve her business skills. She requested a loan of 15,000 PHP. She will use this loan to purchase farm supplies and also buy gasoline for her tractor. She is hopeful that this loan will help her farm grow.

loans.use: Farm supplies

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more African attire

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en: Mercy is a rice farmer living in a town in Agusan del Sur. She is 33 years old, married, and has three children. Her oldest is only 13 and is studying. Mercy wants her farm to be productive, so she does her best to keep it in good condition. She also sought financial assistance from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. She applied for a loan of 15,000 PHP. With this loan, Mercy will be able to purchase the farm supplies necessary for her farm to be productive.

loans.use: Farm supplies

loans.name: Amalia

texts.en:
Amalia, 43 years old, is married to Delfinito P.. They are blessed with four children, the oldest of whom is 24 years old. Amalia is a rice farmer. She makes sure to spend enough time at the farm and also save time for her children. She wants all her children to finish school someday and find decent jobs for themselves; that’s why she finds ways to save.

Amalia is a member of Community Economic Ventures, Inc. Her previous loans were used for farm financing. She is currently applying for a loan of 14,000 PHP. This loan will be used for farm supplies such as seeds and fertilizers. Receiving this loan is truly beneficial to Amalia and her family.

loans.use: Farm supplies

loans.name: Ofelia

texts.en:
Ofelia is a 60-year-old farmer. She explains that, even at her age, she can still manage to perform farming duties. She has been married for 30 years, and she has four children. Her oldest child, who is 39 years old, does not live with the family anymore.

Ofelia does not have sufficient capital to satisfy her farm’s financial needs, so she joined CEVI to gain access to its loan service and for other benefits. She is seeking a loan in the amount of 15,000 PHP ($325), which she will use to purchase seeds, fertilizers, and other farming necessities. With the loan proceeds, she will also purchase diesel for her tractor.

loans.use: To improve her business by purchasing farming necessities (e.g., seeds, fertilizers, and fuel)

loans.name: Nulu

texts.en:
Nulu is a 47-year-old married woman with six children aged between 10 and 20. All her children go to school. She resides in and owns a four-roomed house where she is staying with eight people. Nulu takes care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity but no piped water and gets three meals a day.

Nulu incurs transport costs to and from buying human medicines from pharmacies and drug manufactures in Uganda. She works in a semi-urban area which is on the outskirts of Kampala. Nulu works six days a week .She receives an average of 20 customers a day and sells to all categories of people. She owns a drug shop in Bwaise, paying monthly rent of 60000/=. Her major business challenges are seasonality and thieves.

Nulu has been in this business for nineteen years and with MCDT for seven years, servicing her fourteenth loan. She wants to use this loan to buy more boxes of drugs and syrups. She is aspiring of seeing her business grow bigger and owning a permanent nursing home.

loans.use: To buy boxes of drugs and syrups

loans.name: Herlita

texts.en:
Herlita is a 28-year-old married woman with two children. Her oldest child is just 10 years old. To earn a living, she is engaged in the business of rice farming. When she started her business, she used to deal with traders. However, because of the high interest charged by the traders, Herlita’s income could not cover all of her family’s needs. In addition, the the high interest rate did not allow her to save any money, which she has been planning to do for some time now.

So, as soon as she heard about CEVI, she fulfilled her loan obligations to the traders and joined the MFI. For one thing, the low interest rate appealed to her. When she became a member, she was happy to learn that there are many benefits of micro-finance. She is now seeking a loan in the amount of 15,000 PHP ($325), which she will use to finance her farm. Specifically, she will use the loan proceeds to buy diesel for the tractor and farming necessities, and to pay the laborers who work at the farm.

loans.use: To improve her business by purchasing farming necessities and by paying laborers

loans.name: Medina

texts.en:
Medina is a 37-year-old married woman with two young kids. Her oldest child is 3 years old. She married her husband, Julian, in 1996, and she explains that she loves taking care of her family. She is engaged in the business of rice farming to meet her family's daily needs, but she notes that she also wants to save money for her children’s future. She is currently preparing her land for planting.

She applied to CEVI to gain access to its financial program. She is requesting a loan in the amount of 14,000 PHP ($300). With the loan proceeds, she would like to purchase farming necessities, such as diesel for the tractor, and to pay her laborers. Medina will be happy to use this loan for her business because she knows that it will enable her to save more income in the future.

loans.use: To expand her business by purchasing farming necessities and by paying her laborers

loans.name: Beatriz

texts.en:
Beatriz is a 65-year-old woman with nine children. Her oldest child, who is 34 years old, does not live with the family anymore. Even at 65 years old, Beatriz explains that she is still capable of performing farming duties. As an additional source of income, she purchased pigs.

Beatriz is a member of CEVI. She is currently requesting a loan in the amount of 5,000 PHP ($125), which she will use to buy seeds, fertilizers, and other farming necessities. She is confident that this loan will help expand her farm and, in turn, provide for her family’s needs.

loans.use: To expand her farm by purchasing farming necessities (e.g., seeds and fertilizers)

loans.name: Kasifa

texts.en:
Kasifa is a 40-year-old married woman with six children aged between 10 and 20. All her children go to school. She resides in and owns a five-roomed house where she is staying with eight people. Kasifa takes care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity and piped water and gets three meals a day.

Kasifa incurs transport costs to and from buying charcoal from villages of Mubende, one of the districts in central Uganda, and she uses public transport to and from Mubende. She works in a semi-urban area which is on the outskirts of Kampala. Kasifa works six days a week. She receives an average of twenty customers a day and sells to all categories of people. She doesn’t pay monthly rent, since she works from her home. Her major business challenges are increasing prices of charcoal and transportation.

Kasifa has been in this business for ten years and with MCDT for twelve years, servicing her twentieth loan. She wants to use this loan to buy more sacks of charcoal for her shop. She is aspiring of seeing her business grow bigger and starting selling wholesale only.

loans.use: To buy more sacks of charcoal

loans.name: Nemia

texts.en:
Nemia M. is a 33-year-old married woman from Agusan Del Sur. She has two children, the oldest of whom is only 5 years old. She is engaged in the rice farming business to meet her family's day-to-day needs. Like her other farmer friends, she has had to deal with traders in connection with her business, which--due to the high interest rates the traders charge--makes earning money difficult.

Now Nemia feels fortunate to be a member of CEVI, an MFI in the Philippines and also a KIVA partner. She is applying for a loan in the amount of 15,000 PHP ($325). With the loan proceeds, she would like to purchase farming necessities, like fertilizers, and to pay the laborers she hired to work at her farm.

loans.use: To improve her business by purchasing farming necessities and by paying laborers

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en:
Gloria is a 49-year-old married woman. Indeed, she explains that she has been married to her husband, Henry, for 26 years already. They are blessed with two children, the oldest of whom is 24 years old. Gloria is engaged in the rice farming business. She used to acquire farming necessities from sellers that charge high interest rates; as a result, she generated minimal income and was not able to save any money for future needs.

However, Gloria is now a member of Community Economic Ventures, Inc., and she is extremely thankful for the low interest rate charged by CEVI. She is applying for a loan in the amount of 15,000 PHP ($325). With the loan proceeds, she would like to purchase farm inputs, like seeds and fertilizers. Gloria is hopeful that she will generate higher income from the next harvest.

loans.use: To improve her business by purchasing farming necessities (e.g., seeds and fertilizers)

loans.name: Jevelyn

texts.en:
Jevelyn is 32 years-old and a farmer who lives in a town in Agusan Del Sur. She is married and has five children who go to school. She has learned farming skills in order to maintain the farm in good conditon. She aims for her farm to be productive so that she can earn an income for her family.

Jevely joined Kiva partner CEVI to avail of its financial services and to improve her business skills. She is applying for a loan of Php 13,000. This loan will be used for farm supplies and other farming necessities.

loans.use: To purchase farm supplies.

loans.name: Lilia

texts.en: Lilia is a 47-year-old married woman. She has four children with the oldest 28 years-old. She resides in a town in Agusan Del Sur. She farms rice for a living. She currently owns a two hectare rice field. According to her, the farm needs additional capital. She joined Kiva partner CEVI and applied for a loan of Php 14,000 which she will use to buy seeds, fertilizers and other farm supplies. This loan will be helpful to Lilia as she aims to grow her farm considerably.

loans.use: To purchase farm supplies.

loans.name: Flordeliza

texts.en:
Flordeliza is a mother of three. She is 33 years-old and has been married to her husband Reynaldo for 15 years. Her oldest child is fourteen. She is a farmer and cultivates her land for rice crops. Work at the farm is exhausting but Flordeliza finds a way to find it enjoyable. Being the only source of income, she ensures her farm’s good condition.

Flordeliza joined Kiva partner CEVI in May 2009. She used her previous loan to finance her farm. Now she needs additional capital. She is applying for a loan of Php 8,000 and will use this loan to buy needed farm supplies.

loans.use: To purchase farm supplies.

loans.name: Virgie

texts.en: Virgie is 38 years-old and a farmer who lives in a town in Agusan Del Sur. She plants rice, which is one of the main agricultural crops in her area. She has been married to Eugenio for 20 years. Despite the difficulties in farming, Virgie still finds time to be happy and thankful for her business. She is also grateful that Kiva partner CEVI opened in her town and extended its financial service to farmers like her. She is applying for a loan of Php 8,000, which she will use to buy farm supplies such as seeds, fertilizers, etc. This loan will help Virgie with her farming and eventually her family life.

loans.use: To purchase farm supplies.

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en: 48-year-old Gloria M. is a married woman who lives in Agusan Del Sur. She invested in rice farming and now owns her own rice field. She is preparing her land for planting. Financially short, she joined Kiva partner CEVI in May 2009 to gain access to its financial services. She is now requesting a loan of Php 8,000, which she will use to purchase fertilizers and other farming necessities. This is Gloria’s second loan from CEVI. Her first loan was also used to finance her farm.

loans.use: To purchase farm supplies.

loans.name: Nelly

texts.en:
Nelly is 30 years old and has been married to her husband George for 12 years. They have five children, and the oldest is 12 years old. 

Nelly does rice farming for a living. She said that farming is very important to her because it provides her family’s needs and enables her to pay for her children’s education. Aside from farming, she also raises pigs and chickens that serve as another source of income.

Nelly is a member of CEVI and is grateful for the financial service she gained access to. She is now requesting Php 8,000. She will use this loan to buy seeds, fertilizers and other farm supplies she needs at her farm.

loans.use: To buy seeds, fertilizers, and other farm supplies

loans.name: Rhona

texts.en:
Rhona is 37 and married with seven children aged between 5 and 18 years. All her children go to school. She resides in and owns a six-roomed house where she is staying with ten people. Rhona takes care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity and piped water and gets three meals a day.

Rhona incurs transport costs to and from buying charcoal from villages of Luwero, one of the districts of central Uganda, and uses public transport to and from Luwero. She works in a semi-urban area which is on the outskirts of Kampala. Rhona works seven days a week. She receives an average of 40 customers a day and sells to all categories of people, both wholesale and retail. She doesn’t pay monthly rent as she works from her home. Her major business challenges are the rainy season and transportation.

Rhona has been in this business for seven years and with MCDT for twelve years. She wants to use this loan to buy more sacks of charcoal for her shop. She is aspiring of seeing her business grower bigger and starting selling wholesale only.

loans.use: To buy more sacks of charcoal

loans.name: Rochie

texts.en: 22-year-old Rochie is the young mother of a 1-year-old child. Because she is new to having her own family, she sought her mother’s advice in raising a family. She also invested in rice farming to earn a living. She is now preparing her rice field for the next planting. She needs seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs, so she requested a loan of Php 8,000 from Community Economic Ventures, Inc., where she is a member. This loan will truly help Rochie immensely in growing her farm.

loans.use: To purchase seeds, fertilizers, and other farm supplies

loans.name: Teopista

texts.en:
Teopista is 46 and married with five children. All her children go to school. She resides in and owns a four-roomed house where she is staying with eight people. Teopista takes care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity and piped water and gets three meals a day.

Teopista doesn’t incur any transport costs as she buys from her home from delivery trucks which get charcoal from villages. She works in a semi-urban area which is on the outskirts of Kampala. Teopista works seven days a week. She receives an average of 40 customers a day and sells to all categories of people both wholesale and retail. She doesn’t pay monthly rent as she works from her home.

Teopista‘s monthly expenses include school fees and feeding the family. Her major business challenges are the rainy season and transportation. She has been in this business for ten years and with MCDT for twelve years. She wants to use this loan to buy more sacks of charcoal. She is aspiring of seeing her business grow bigger and starting selling wholesale only.

loans.use: To buy more sacks of charcoal

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is 30 and married with four children aged between 4 and 13 years. All her children go to school. She resides in and rents a four-roomed house where she is staying with eight people. Mary takes care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity but no piped water and gets three meals a day.

Mary incurs transport costs to and from buying charcoal from villages. She works in a semi-urban area which is on the outskirts of Kampala. Mary has a charcoal store in Ndeeba town and pays 30000/=as monthly rent charges. She works seven days a week. She receives an average of 30 customers a day and sells to all categories of people both wholesale and retail.

Mary's greatest monthly expenses include feeding the family, medications, and school fees. Her major business challenges are transportation and the rainy season which hinders her customers from reaching her because she works from an area that floods.

Mary has been in this business for ten years and with MCDT for three years, servicing her tenth loan. She wants to use this loan to buy more sacks of charcoal. She is aspiring of seeing her business grow bigger and starting selling wholesale only.

loans.use: To buy more  sacks of charcoal

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is 30 years old and married with four children between the ages of four and 13. All her children go to school. She resides in a rented four room house where she stays with eight people. Mary takes care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity but no piped water, and gets three meals a day.

Mary works in a semi-urban area which is on the outskirts of Kampala. She incurs transport costs to and from buying charcoal from villages. Mary has a charcoal store in Ndeeba town and pays 30000/= for monthly rent charges. She works seven days a week. She receives an average of 30 customers a day and sells to all categories of people, both in wholesale and retail. Her greatest monthly expenses include feeding the family, medication and school fees. Her major business challenges are transportation and the rainy season, which hinders her customers from reaching out to her because she works in an area that floods. She has been in this business for ten years and with MCDT for three years, now servicing her tenth loan. She wants to use this loan to buy more sacks of charcoal. She aspires to see her business grower bigger and to start selling wholesale only.

loans.use: To buy more sacks of charcoal

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence is 52 years old and married with four children between the ages of 18 and 32. Two of her children go to school. She owns and resides in a five room house where she stays with six people. Florence takes care of additional family members. The family has no access to electricity or piped water, and gets three meals a day.

Florence works in a semi-urban area which is on the outskirts of Kampala. She incurs transport costs to and from buying chicken from poultry farmers. She owns a stall in Kalerwe market selling chicken of all types, including local layers and broilers. She works seven days a week. She receives an average of 30 customers a day and sells to all categories of people, both in retail and wholesale. Her greatest monthly expenses include feeding the family and school fees for her children. Her major business challenges are transportation and thieves. She has been in this business for fifteen years and with MCDT for nine years, now servicing her twenty-third loan and working with the same group mates. Florence joined MCDT because it was near her home amd works with poor women. She wants to use this loan to buy more chicken. She aspires to see her business grow bigger, to start selling wholesale only, and to farm poultry.

loans.use: To buy more chicken for resale

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret is 36 years old and married with four children between the ages of five and 12. All her children go to school. She owns and resides in a five room house where she stays with seven people. Margaret takes care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity but no piped water, and gets three meals a day.

Margaret works in a semi-urban area which is on the outskirts of Kampala. She incurs transport costs to and from buying ground nuts from Owino market, one of the busiest markets in Uganda. She owns a shop selling ground nuts, both squeezed and as cereal. She works seven days a week. She receives an average of five customers a day and sells to all categories of people, both in retail and wholesale. Her greatest monthly expenses include feeding the family and school fees for her children. Her major business challenges are transportation and thieves. She has been in this business for fifteen years and with MCDT for ten years, now servicing her twenty third loan and working with the same group mates. Margaret joined MCDT because it was near her home and works with poor women. She wants to use this loan to buy more sacks of ground nuts. She aspires to see her business grow bigger and to start selling wholesale only.

loans.use: To buy more sacks of ground nuts

loans.name: Bawji

texts.en:
Bawji is a 45 year old single mother of two children aged between 17 and 20. Both her children go to school. She owns and resides in a five room house where she stays with seven people. Bawji takes care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity and piped water and gets three meals a day.

She works in a semi-urban area which is on the outskirts of Kampala. Bawji goes door to door selling African attire and ladies hand bags. She incurs transport costs to and from buying African attire and ladies hand bags from DRC (Democratic Republic of Congo). She works seven days a week. She receives an average of five customers a day and sells to all categories of people in retail. Her greatest monthly expenses include feeding her family and school fees for her children. Her major business challenges are transportation and seasonality. She has been in this business for ten years and with MCDT for seven years, now servicing her sixteenth loan. She wants to use this loan to buy more rolls of African attire (bitengi) and ladies hand bags. She aspires to see her business grow bigger, to start selling wholesale only, and to also own a permanent business premise.

loans.use: To buy more African ware and hand bags

loans.name: Ann Mary Mugisha‘S Group

texts.en: Ann Mary is a 65 year single mother of eight children aged between 30 and 43 years. They all completed school. She owns and lives in a four room house with seven people. AnnMary takes care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity and piped water and gets three meals a day. She incurs transport costs to and from buying merchandise from Kikuubo (one of the busiest places in Kampala city). She works in a semi urban area which is in the outskirts of Kampala. Ann Mary owns a retail shop in Nsooba Kyebando and doesn’t pay for rent because she owns the business premises. She works seven days a week. She receives an average of 30 customers a day and sells to all categories of people. Besides this retail shop, she also owns a poultry farm with 200 laying chicken. Her greatest monthly expenses include feeding the family, and school fees for her grand children. Her major business challenges are transportation and thieves. She has been in this business for ten years and with MCDT for seven years servicing her sixteenth loan. She wants to use this loan to buy more merchandise like boxes of soap, jerrycans of cooking oil and chicken feed. She aspires to see her business grower bigger and to start selling on wholesale only and also owning 1000 laying chickens.

loans.use: To buy more merchandise for resale

loans.name: Fatumah

texts.en: Fatumah is a 50 years old, married, and has seven children aged between 15 and 32 years. Three of her children go to school. She owns and lives in a six room house with eleven people. Fatumah takes care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity and no piped water and gets three meals a day. She incurs transport costs to and from buying vegetables and fruits from Nakawa Market to her stall in the Naguru Kasenke Zone.  She works in a semi urban area which is in the outskirts of Kampala. She works seven days a week. She receives an average of thirty customers a day and sells to all categories of people both retail and wholesale. Her greatest monthly expenses include feeding the family and school fees for her children. Her major business challenges are transportation and seasonality She has been in this business for fifteen years and with MCDT for seven years servicing her twentieth loan, working with the same group mates. Fatumah joined MCDT because it was near her home and was working with poor women. She wants to use this loan to buy more boxes of tomatoes, onions, mangoes and jack fruits. She aspires to see her business grower bigger and starts selling on wholesale only and also going directly to farmers.

loans.use: To buy more fruits and vegetables for resale

loans.name: Resty

texts.en: Resty is a 52 years old, widowed with five children aged between 15 and 32 years.  Three of her children go to school. She resides in and owns a two room house where she is staying with twelve people. Resty takes care of additional family members. The family has no access to electricity and piped water and gets three meals a day. She incurs transport costs to and from buying charcoal from Kisaasi to her home at Kisaasi Kikulu zone. She doesn’t pay rent for business premises because she sells from her home. She works in a semi urban area which is in the outskirts of Kampala. She works seven days a week. She receives an average of thirty customers a day and sells to all categories of people both on retail and wholesale. Her greatest monthly expenses include feeding the family and school fees for her children. Her major business challenges are transportation and seasonality. She has been in this business for six years and with MCDT for ten years servicing her twentieth loan, working with the same group mates. Resty joined MCDT because it was near her home and was working with poor women. She wants to use this loan to buy more sacks of charcoal for use during the festive season. She aspires to see her business grower bigger and starts selling on wholesale only and also going directly to producers.

loans.use: To buy more sacks of charcoal

loans.name: Kirabo

texts.en: C. is a 35 years old and married with two children aged 4 and 9 years. All her children go to school. She resides in and rents a two room house where she is staying with four people. C. takes care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity and no piped water and gets three meals a day. She incurs transport costs to and from buying religious items like Rosaries, bibles and booklets. She doesn’t pay rent because she moves from church to church. She works in a semi urban area which is in the outskirts of Kampala. She works seven days a week. She receives an average of ten customers a day and sells to all categories of people both on retail and wholesale. Her greatest monthly expenses include feeding the family and school fees for her children. Her major business challenges are transportation and seasonality. She has been in this business for eight years and with MCDT for four years servicing her twelfth loan, working with the same group mates. C. joined MCDT because it was near her home and was working with poor women. She wants to use this loan to buy more boxes of Rosaries, bibles, candles and other religious booklet. She aspires to see her business grower bigger and to start selling on wholesale only and also going directly to producers

loans.use: To buy more rosaries, candles, bibles and religious booklets

loans.name: Harriet

texts.en: Harriet is a 39 years old and married with five children aged between10 and 20 years. All her children go to school. She resides in and owns a three roomed house where she is staying with eight people. Harriet takes care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity and piped water and gets three meals a day. She incurs transport costs to and from shopping in Nakawa market to her retails shop in Naguru Godown Zone. She rents her business premise sat 100000/= per monthly. She works in a semi urban area which is in the outskirts of Kampala  She works seven days a week. She receives an average of 40 customers a day and sells to all categories of people both on retail and wholesale. Her greatest monthly expenses include feeding the family, school fees for her children and rent for her business premise. Her major business challenges are defaulters and rainy season which hinders her ability to to reach her customers. She has been in this business for eighteen years and with MCDT for eight years servicing her seventeenth loan, working with the same group mates. Harriet joined MCDT because it was near her home and was working with poor women. She wants to use this loan to buy more merchandise for her retail shop like boxes of soap, cartons of salt, bags of sugar and cooking oil. She is aspiring of seeing her business grower bigger and start selling on wholesale only and also getting a permanent business premise.

loans.use: To buy more cartons of salt, bags of sugar and cooking oil

loans.name: Kasifa

texts.en:
Kasifa is a 45-year-old widow with six children aged from 15 to 20 years, two of whom go to school. She also takes care of additional family members. She resides in and owns a three-roomed house where she lives with six people. The family has access to electricity and piped water and gets three meals a day. Her greatest monthly expenses include feeding the family and school fees for her children.

Kasifa works in a semi-urban area which is in the outskirts of Kampala. She incurs transport costs to and from her work in Nakawa market. She has a stall selling yellow bananas and buys from her place of work from suppliers who get them from the villages. She doesn’t pay rent for her business but pays daily market dues of 800 UGX per day worked.

Kasifa works seven days a week. She receives an average of ten customers a day and sells to all categories of people both in retail and wholesale. Her major business challenges are defaulters and the rainy season which hinders her from reaching her customers.

Kasifa has been in this business for twenty years and with MCDT for nine years and is servicing her thirtieth loan, working with the same group members. Kasifa joined MCDT because it was near her home and it was working with poor women. She wants to use this loan to buy more bunches and clusters of yellow bananas.

Kasifa is aspiring to seeing her business grow bigger and to start selling wholesale only and also to getting permanent business premises.

loans.use: To buy more bunches and clusters of yellow bananas

loans.name: Jane

texts.en: Jane is a 39 years old and married with five children aged between 10 and 20 years. All her children go to school. She resides in and owns a three room house where she is staying with eight people. Jane takes care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity and piped water and gets three meals a day. She doesn’t incur any transport costs as she buys from her place of work. She has a stall selling all food stuffs like bananas, cassava, sweet and Irish potatoes in Mengo mackay. She pays dues of 1000/= per day. She works in a semi urban area which is in the outskirts of Kampala  She works seven days a week. She receives an average of 40 customers a day and sells to all categories of people both on retail and wholesale.  Her greatest monthly expenses include feeding the family and school fees for her children and rent for her business premise. Her major business challenges are defaulters and the rainy season which hinders her to reach her customers. She has been in this business for eighteen years and with MCDT for eight years servicing her seventeenth loan, working with the same group mates. Jane joined MCDT because it was near her home and was working with poor women. She wants to use this loan to buy more bunches of bananas, cassava, sweet and Irish potatoes. She is aspiring of seeing her business grower bigger and start going directly to farmers.

loans.use: To buy more bunches of bananas, cassava and irish potatoes

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: Stock their businesses

loans.name: Jelly

texts.en: Jelly, 34, is a farmer who owns a rice field in Surallah, South Cotabato. She is married to Arsenio and has a 9-year-old child. The income from her farm helps a lot in sustaining their every day living. She wants to improve her farming so she can have a bigger harvest in the future. She joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc. requesting a loan of 12,000 Philippine pesos to buy fertilizers and farm supplies. This loan will help provide additional capital for her business.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and farm supplies

loans.name: Maria's Group

texts.es: Las 5 señoras de San Juan La laguna viendo sus necesidad para surtir las ventas para este fin de año y quiere incrementar sus mercaderia para compertir en la compra y venta de ropa tipica ya que ellas lo vienen realizando por 5 años atras y ellas quieren que le se apoyen para esta necesidad ya que tienen la mentalidad de superar y darles lo mejor para sus hijos y apoyararles en sus estudios por lo tanT. suplican para poder ayudarles en este sentido, ya que en el lugar donde se encuentra es un lugar muy pobre y que les a costado salir avante, y ellas mismas bordan a mano y como tambien fabrican las blusas para mujeres,
texts.en:
The five women that form the San Juan La Laguna group see the need T. provide their sales numbers for the end of year and would like T. increase their merchandise so they can compete in the buying and selling of traditional clothing. They have been selling for five years and they would like your support as they have the intention of overcoming obstacles and doing what is best for their children. They support their children with their studies and so they beg T. be able T. help in this regard as they live in a very poor place. The women also embroider by hand and make blouses for women.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Sindewald, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to increase merchandise of traditional clothing

loans.name: Landy

texts.en:
Landy started his rice farming business in 2008 and tills his land very well to make a good harvest.

Landy needs additional capital to finance his business and that's why he joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc. He has requested a loan of 15,000 Php which will be enough to buy farm supplies necessary for his rice field.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies

loans.name: Lourdes

texts.en:
Lourdes loves to be a farmer. She does rice farming for a living. The 2-hectare (5-acre) piece of land they have is where they get their source of living. With proper maintenance and land preparation, they will reap a good harvest.

Lourdes requested a loan from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. to support her business. She asked for 15,000 Php which will be used to buy farm supplies.

Lourdes is married to Victor and they have two children. Her eldest is 17 years old.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies

loans.name: Manuel

texts.en:
Manuel, 29, has a rice farming business in Surallah, South Cotabato. Being single, he devotes much of his time to focusing on his farm's development. He started farming in 1998. With more experience in farming, he is confident of having a good harvest.

Manuel joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc. to obtain a loan that will be used for his business. He would like to request 8,000 Php to purchase farm inputs.

loans.use: To buy farm inputs

loans.name: Margarita

texts.en:
Hog raising is the main source of income of Margarita. She is already 61 years old but active enough to manage a piggery to sustain her family. She has nine children to support and that's why she works hard to earn a living.

Margarita heard about Community Economic Ventures, Inc. and liked its program to help entrepreneurs like her. Additional capital is what she longs to have in order to expand her business. She is now requesting a loan of 15,000 Php to buy more piglets and pig feed.

loans.use: To purchase piglets and pig feed

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
64-year-old Maria T. is managing both hog raising and rice farming businesses. She owns three hectares (7.5 acres) of land in Surallah, South Cotabato. She maximized every resource she has to become productive.

Maria joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc. to obtain a loan to raise capital for her businesses. She needs financial support at this time to have success in her businesses. She requested a loan of 15,000 Php to buy three more pigs and to pay for farm inputs.

loans.use: To buy three more pigs and to pay for farm inputs

loans.name: Marilou

texts.en:
Marilou, 38, has three businesses: a piggery, rice farming, and a sari-sari (variety) store. The eldest of her five children is still 15 years old and that's why she works hard in order to support them.

Marilou requested a loan of 8,000 Php from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. to buy supplies needed for her businesses. She would like to expand her businesses in order to earn more for the sustenance of her family.

loans.use: To buy feeds and farm supplies

loans.name: Marivic

texts.en: Marivic has applied for a loan for PHP 13,000 to buy the supplies and materials she needs for her rice farm. She is committed to meet the needs of her family, and also runs a small cosmetic business on the side. Marivic is a single mother who works very hard and takes exceptionally good care of her one child, who is eight years old.

loans.use: to buy additional supplies for her farm

loans.name: Erika Del Carmen

texts.es: La joven Ericka García  trabaja en una librería desde hace un año, y los fines de semana hace sopa, vigoron, y una variedad de alimentos los domingos  para ganar un poco mas, vive juntos con sus padres en el barrio la Esperanza, tiene 19 años de edad, soltera y con muchos deseos de salir a delante. Uno de sus metas es poder seguir estudiando. Con este financiamiento es para invertir en la compra de materiales de construcción como: piedra,  arena, hierro, cemento para hacer un muro  en frente de la casa, para dar una mejor seguridad, por que muchas veces las pandillas del barrio hacen pleitos en la calle y da mucho miedo y con este muro pondrá una barrera a la delincuencia, a si como mejor presentación, el cual esta contenta por alcanzar estos logros y poder ayudar a sus padres mientras este con ellos ya que son mayores de edad.
texts.en:
Young Ericka G. has worked in a bookstore for a year. On the weekends, she makes soup, pork salad, and a variety of foods to sell in order to earn a little more. She lives with her parents in the Esperanza neighborhood. She is 19 years old, single, and has a strong desire to get ahead. One of her goals is to be able to continue her studies. She will use this financing to invest in the purchase of construction materials such as: stone, sand, iron and cement to make a wall in front of her house for greater security, because many times the gangs in the neighborhood have fights in the street, which is very frightening. With this wall she will be able to put a barrier between these activities and her house, and also improve its appearance. She is very pleased to be able to reach for this goal, and to be able to help her parent while she is with them, since they are older.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy stone, cement, iron to make a wall in front for greater security

loans.name: Hermelinda

texts.es:
Hermelinda tiene 39 años de edad, es madre soltera y tiene tres hijos. Vive junto a su madre en el Pueblo Jóven San Martín, de la ciudad de Lambayeque, ubicada a veinte minutos de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Desde hace más de veinte años se dedica a la venta de diarios y revistas. Ella nos cuenta que empezó a vender junto a su madre en una esquina cercana al mercado de la ciudad y que desde hace cinco años lograron instalarse en un kiosko ubicado en la avenida más transitada de la ciudad. Hermelinda trabaja en su puesto todos los días de seis de la mañana a cinco de la tarde. Este negocio es la principal fuente de ingreso de su familia por lo que día a día da lo mejor de sí para salir adelante.

Hermelinda desea ampliar su negocio con la venta de más revistas , pero no cuenta con el capital suficiente para realizar su objetivo por lo que se encuentra solicitando por primera vez a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 300 nuevos soles.

Ella es una mujer que ha sabido salir adelante a pesar de las dificultades. Su más grande anhelo es seguir trabajando para construir su casa propia y poder brindarle a sus hijos una educación de calidad.
texts.en:
Hermelinda is 39 years old and a single mother of three children. She lives with her mother in the town of Jóven San Martín, in the city of Lambayeque, located twenty minutes from the city of Chiclayo. For twenty years Hermelinda has worked selling newspapers and magazines. She says that she started this business with her mother on a street corner close to the city's market, and that five years ago they managed to set up a kiosk on the busiest street of the city. Hermelinda works the stand every day from six in the morning to 5 in the afternoon. This business is her main source of income for her family, and so she works hard at it every day to get her family ahead. Hermelinda would like to expand her business by adding more magazines to her inventory, but she does not have enough capital to achieve this goal. For this reason she is for the first time asking Edpyme Alternativa for a loan of 300 new soles. Hermelinda is a women who has learned to keep working despite any difficulties. Her greatest wishes are to keep working to build her own house and to be able to give her children a good education.

Translated from Spanish by Kevin Credo, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of magazines to increase inventory.

loans.name: Mary Ann

texts.en:
Rice farming and hog raising are the sources of income of Mary Ann. She is 25 years old married to Levi. They have two children and the eldest is still 5 years old. Together, she and her husband work hard to sustain their family.

Mary Ann requested a loan from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. of 15,000 PHP which will be used to finance her businesses. This will be of great help to fill the needs of her rice field and piggery.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies and pig feed

loans.name: Mary Jean

texts.en:
Mary Jean, 40, is a rice farmer with three children. She has been rice farming since 2000 and tills her rice field to earn a living.

Mary Jean joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc. to have the chance of obtaining a loan for her business. She requested 14,000 Php which is quite enough to fill her need for farm inputs. With your help she will be grateful that she will be able to finance her business, even with the limited capital she has.

loans.use: To buy farm inputs

loans.name: Tomas

texts.es:
El señor Tomas A. esta muy agradecido por su cooperación en el anterior crédito el cual su negocio a crecido y a tenido más ingreso. Con el cual le ha mandado a su familia que viven en Veracruz México.
Nueva mente  esta solicitando su cooperación para un préstamo ya que necesita comprar mercancía y herramienta mas moderna, para las televisiones de plasma.
Don Tomas planea pagar el crédito con una parte de las ganancias D. negocio, ya que tiene que mandarle a su familia a Veracruz.
texts.en:
Mr. Tomas A. is very grateful for the support of his previous loan which has grown his business. He sent this extra income to his family that lives in Veracruz, Mexico.

Now he is asking for your help with another loan as he needs to buy merchandise and more modern tools for repairing plasma screen televisions. Tomas plans to pay off the loan with a portion of the earnings from his business, as he has to send the rest to his family in Veracruz.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Sindewald, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy merchandise and modern tools to repair plasma screen televisions

loans.name: Maria Antonia

texts.es: Doña Maria Antonia trabaja en servicios domésticos, desde hace cinco años, trabajo cansado, y gana poco, madre soltera de tres hijos de los cuales dos emigraron a Costa rica por la mala situación  económica del país, el desempleo, y pagas muy bajos. el pequeño de 7 años lo tiene estudiando su segundo grado en la primaria, Su casa es pequeña y con la necesidad de ganar dinero tomo la iniciativa de alquilar un  cuarto para poder ayudarse con los gastos básicos de agua y luz. Con el crédito anterior lo termino de construir y acondiciono. Y con este financiamiento construirá otro cuarto el cual comprara: piedra, arena, cemento, hierro, zinc, perlines con el fin de  poder ahorrar para un futuro. Ya que tiene 52 años de edad, y siente cansada. Agradece Afodenic por el apoyo con los préstamos a mujeres pobres.
texts.en:
Mrs. Maria Antonia has been working in domestic service for five years, a job that is tiring and low-paying. She is a single mother of three children, two of which immigrated to Costa Rica because of the high unemployment rate, low pay, and bad economic situation in the country.
